Graphical abstract The development of high-temperature-tolerant flexible supercapacitors is essential for expanding their applications in harsh environmental conditions. This necessitates research into specialized gel-polymer electrolytes and electrode materials capable of withstanding extreme heat while delivering superior performance. The development of flexible supercapacitors (FSCs) capable of operating at high temperatures is crucial for expanding the application areas and operating conditions of supercapacitors. Gel polymer electrolytes and electrode materials stand as two key components that significantly impact the efficacy of high-temperature-tolerant FSCs (HT-FSCs). They should not only exhibit high electrochemical performance and excellent flexibility, but also withstand intense thermal stress. Considerable efforts have been devoted to enhancing their thermal stability while maintaining high electrochemical and mechanical performance. In this review, the fundamentals of HT-FSCs are outlined. A comprehensive overview of state-of-the-art progress and achievements in HT-FSCs, with a focus on thermally stable gel polymer electrolytes and electrode materials is provided. Finally, challenges and future perspectives regarding HT-FSCs are discussed, alongside strategies for elevating operational temperatures and performance. This review offers both theoretical foundations and practical guidelines for designing and manufacturing HT-FSCs, further promoting their widespread adoption across diverse fields. Keywords Flexible supercapacitors High-temperature tolerance Gel polymer electrolytes Electrode materials 1 Introduction Supercapacitors (SCs), as a new type of electrochemical energy storage device, have demonstrated advantages such as high-power density, long cycle life, and fast charging and discharging rates [1,2]. However, the operating temperatures of commercial SCs can hardly exceed 65 °C because of the volatility of organic solvents like acetonitrile [3,4]. Elevated temperatures may lead to performance degradation or even cessation of operation of SCs. Moreover, there is a risk of thermal runaway and potential explosions. Therefore, the development of SCs capable of operating at high temperature with high-level safety and performance is in increasing demand. This is of paramount importance for their widespread applications in various fields, including electric vehicles, advanced electronics, and special environments such as oil drilling, mining, military devices, and aerospace industry. The fabrication of (quasi-)solid-state SCs by replacing liquid electrolytes with (quasi-)solid-state electrolytes has been recognized as a wise strategy to achieve heat management of SCs [5]. This also leads to the formation of flexible SCs (FSCs) that have garnered significant attention due to the growing market and rapid development of portable and wearable electronics. FSCs inherit the merits of SCs while also exhibiting excellent mechanical bendability, stretchability, and ease of packaging and molding. Unlike traditional SCs and regular FSCs, high-temperature-tolerant FSCs (HT-FSCs) should possess not only excellent flexibility but also high thermal stability. As two key components of HT-FSCs, electrode materials and electrolytes that can withstand extreme heat are required, which may lead to increased manufacturing complexity and cost. Quasi-solid-state gel polymer electrolytes (GPEs) have been widely used in the construction of FSCs [6]. A GPE, typically composed of a polymer matrix, an electrolytic compound, and a solvent, was first discovered in the 1970s [7]. It serves multiple functions as an electrolyte, a separator, and a binder. By entrapping a liquid electrolyte within a suitable polymeric framework, a GPE combines the diffusivity of a liquid electrolyte with the cohesiveness of a solid electrolyte. It exhibits higher ionic conductivity compared to a solid polymer electrolyte while avoiding the leakage risks associated with a liquid electrolyte [8,9]. Moreover, the properties of GPEs enable the fabrication of FSCs with diverse shapes, reduced weight and thickness, and simplified packaging complexity compared to conventional SCs. However, at high operating temperatures, the volatility of organic solvents and the relatively low melting point of conventional host polymeric matrices may lead to issues such as melting, expansion, structural changes and even collapse of GPEs. To enhance the thermal stability of GPEs and improve the safety and processability of related FSCs, several approaches have been explored. These include the development of water-in-salt (WIS) based GPEs, the formation of ionic liquid GPEs (IL-GPEs or ionogels), the use of mixed solvents like deep eutectic solvents (DESs), the utilization of thermally stable polymers and the incorporation of heat-resistant fillers, etc. Many advanced electrode materials (e.g., carbon materials, metal oxides, conducting polymers and their composites) have been applied in HT-FSCs. To ensure high electrochemical performance of HT-FSCs, it is crucial for them to possess qualities of high specific surface area, good electrical conductivity, compatibility with utilized electrolytes and effective accessibility of electrolyte ions to internal pore regions. Their flexibility and thermal stability are essential for maintaining high performance under diverse environmental and operational conditions. An elevated operating temperature shows impacts on kinetics of electrochemical/chemical reactions, side reactions, and electrolytic/thermal decomposition reactions within electrodes [10,11]. Additionally, it influences the volume and structure of electrodes, as well as the charge/ion transfer behavior within them, resulting in varied electrochemical performance (e.g., capacitance, cycling stability and resistance) [12]. For example, an elevated temperature can induce the deposition of solid reaction products, possibly stemming from decomposition processes at electrode/electrolyte interfaces [13]. These deposits may subsequently clog the pores in electrode materials, reducing their effective surface area. Therefore, a comprehensive understanding of the thermal characteristics of electrode materials and their effect on electrochemical performance becomes imperative. To date, there have been few reviews dealing with high-temperature-tolerant FSCs, with even fewer exploring electrode materials in depth. Considering that a series of works have been reported recently on the development of new GPEs and novel electrode materials for thermally stable FSCs, it is necessary to summarize the current state-of-the-art achievements to gain a comprehensive understanding of the latest research, which will offer valuable guidance for future investigations. This review starts from the fundamentals of HT-FSCs, followed by an overview of the progress of GPEs and electrode materials used for the fabrication of HT-FSCs. Since there is a noticeable lag in the development of functional GPEs compared to advanced electrode materials, this review will prioritize the discussion on the design and preparation of GPEs, focusing on the strategies for achieving thermally stable GPEs. The remaining challenges and future perspectives are also outlined and discussed for the development of HT-FSCs with high performance. 2 Principles of HT-FSCs 2.1 Structure and charge storage mechanism Like regular FSCs, HT-FSCs commonly consist of two electrodes separated by an electrolyte, and can be designed in different shapes with various dimensions. A conventional sandwich-structured HT-FSC is assembled by sandwiching a layer of GPEs between two flexible electrodes (Fig. 1 a). In case that different GPEs are employed for the cathode and anode, a membrane is then used to separate the negative and positive compartments. In a planar design, two thin-film electrodes are interdigitated in-plane, with the interdigitated pattern area being coated by a GPE (Fig. 1b). Such a configuration with improved space utilization makes the device more compatible, shortens the ion diffusion pathway, and improves charge transfer kinetics. A fiber-shaped HT-FSC integrates two fiber electrodes separated by a GPE (Fig. 1c). With good formability, it can be processed into nearly any preferred shape. Same as conventional SCs and regular FSCs, electrical double layer capacitors (EDLCs) and pseudocapacitors (PCs) are two types of HT-FSCs with different charge storage mechanisms (Fig. 1d, e). In an EDLC, charges are stored electrostatically (non-Faradaic) purely via charge adsorption and accumulation at the electrode interfaces, thus allowing fast charging and discharging processes. Carbon materials with various forms, such as activated carbon (AC), carbon nanotube (CNT), graphene, etc., have been mostly investigated and used for EDLCs due to their large specific surface areas, high porosity, and excellent electrochemical stability [14]. PCs based on redox-active electrode materials store charges via Faradaic processes at the electrode/electrolyte interfaces, resulting in additional pseudocapacitance. Several Faradaic mechanisms have been proposed including underpotential deposition, redox processes, and intercalation of ions [15]. Transition metal compounds (e.g., oxides and carbides) and conducting polymers like polyaniline (PANI) and polypyrrole (PPy) have been used as pseudocapacitive electrode materials. With the additional pseudocapacitance, PCs typically reveal higher capacitance and energy density than EDLCs [16]. However, pseudocapacitive materials often possess relatively poor electrical conductivity, impeding efficient charge and electron transfer within the system, thus lowering the power density [17]. Additionally, these materials often suffer from relatively poor cyclic stability because of structural degradation during Faradaic processes. To address these problems, they are usually combined with capacitive carbonaceous materials. Carbonaceous materials with high specific surface area, high porosity, and high conductivity can not only enhance the rate performance and power density but also effectively buffer volume changes during charging/discharging cycling to ensure a prolonged lifespan of energy storage devices. In the case that a soluble redox electrolyte is employed, the SC is then referred to as a redox-electrolyte enhanced SC (R-SC) (Fig. 1f) [18]. Different from the charge storage mechanism of PCs, which typically use inert electrolytes, R-SCs store charges through diffusion-controlled Faradaic processes involving soluble redox species within electrolytes at the electrode surface. Depending on the design and charge storage mechanisms, HT-FSCs can be categorized into symmetric and asymmetric ones. Symmetric devices feature identical positive and negative electrode/electrolyte systems, which exhibit similar electrochemical behavior during charging/discharging processes. The charge storage is conducted on the surface of both electrodes via electrostatic adsorption of ions or Faradaic redox reactions. In asymmetric ones, dissimilar positive and negative electrode/electrolyte systems are present, encompassing variations in the type and structure of electrode materials, and redox-active electrolytes, etc. The charge storage mechanisms may either be consistent or differ. When incorporating a traditional capacitor-like electrode alongside a battery-type electrode, asymmetric SCs are also referred to as hybrid SCs [19]. Metal-ion SCs represent a specific subset within this classification. This combination achieves a balance between the high-power density of the capacitive electrode/electrolyte system and the high energy density of the battery-like one, making the assembled devices suitable for a wide range of applications. 2.2 Performance evaluation The electrochemical, mechanical and thermal performances of HT-FSCs (e.g., capacitance, impedance, energy and power densities, self-discharging behavior, long-term stability, and flexibility, etc.) are evaluated at elevated temperatures. Compared to traditional SCs and regular FSCs, the research of HT-FSCs primarily focuses on understanding the impact of temperature on their performance and the associated mechanisms. 2.2.1 Electrochemical performance The specific capacitance of an HT-FSC can be estimated from cyclic voltammograms (CVs) or galvanostatic charging/discharging (GCD) curves according to Eqs. (1) and (2), respectively. (1) C = ∫ I d V Δ V v X (2) C = I × t dc Δ V X where C is the specific capacitance, I the discharging current, V the applied voltage, v the scan rate, and t dc the discharging time in a GCD curve. The symbol X refers to the effective mass, geometric area or volume of active electrode materials. In some research, the specific capacitance is also calculated by considering the overall volume of the entire device, encompassing electrodes, electrolyte, and other components. Energy density (E) is a measure of the amount of energy stored within an HT-FSC relative to its unit volume or mass, which can be determined using the following equation [20]. (3) E = 1 2 C Δ V 2 When the GCD curves for a system are nonlinear, the energy density derived from the discharging sections of these curves should be calculated using Eq. (4) [18,19]. (4) E = ∫ I V d t X The term power density (P) serves as a metric to quantify the rate at which an HT-FSC can store or discharge energy. This value can be calculated according to Eqs. (5) or (6). (5) P = Δ V 2 4 R s X (6) P = E t dc where R s refers to equivalent series resistance, corresponding to the sum of various types of resistances including the intrinsic electrical resistance of the electrode material, the contact resistance between the electrode and the current collector, the electrolyte resistance, and the mass transfer resistance of the ions, etc. Cycling stability is a critical parameter to assess the ability of an HT-FSC to sustain consistent and reliable performance throughout an extended duration of operation. It is commonly assessed by examining changes in capacitance, or other performance metrics (e.g., energy density) over numerous charging/discharging cycles under given conditions. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) is a powerful technique used to evaluate the impedance of HT-FSCs and understand the charge transfer processes at the electrode/electrolyte interfaces. EIS measures the current response of a system to a small sinusoidal voltage applied across a range of frequencies, allowing the extraction of impedance information by analyzing the phase and amplitude differences at varying frequencies [21,22]. EIS data can be fitted by equivalent circuit models, which incorporate parameters such as internal resistance, charge transfer resistance, and double-layer capacitance. The values of these circuit elements offer insights into the electrochemical system, such as the impact of temperature on the charge transfer kinetics, and the reasons behind variations in electrochemical performance during durability tests. The self-discharging characteristics of an energy storage device are important for assessing its shelf life or the ability to maintain stored energy over time. The gradual loss of stored energy can be attributed to some internal processes such as chemical reactions and/or current leakage, even during standby periods [23]. The measurement of self-discharging behavior involves charging a device to a specified voltage, disconnecting it from an external circuit, and monitoring the voltage decay over a set duration. The rate at which the voltage decreases over time serves as an indicator of the self-discharging kinetics and the capability of the device to retain stored energy. The Coulombic efficiency, often referred to as charging/discharging efficiency, is generally calculated as the ratio of the charge output during discharging to the charge input during charging. It should ideally be close to 100%, suggesting that nearly all the charge stored during charging is released during discharging processes. However, at elevated temperatures, the Coulombic efficiency of FSCs tends to decrease. The possible reasons for this decline include: (i) accelerated degradation and aging of electrolytes and electrode materials at higher temperatures, leading to narrowed electrochemical voltage window, reduced effective surface area for energy storage, increased self-discharging rates and loss of stored charge; (ii) promoted unwanted side reactions at the electrode–electrolyte interface, consuming charge without contributing to the energy storage process; (iii) alterations at the electrode–electrolyte interface, such as the formation of passive layers or other insulating phases that impede ion transport; (iv) the breakdown of the separator and other internal components, creating pathways for unintended current flow. 2.2.2 Flexibility The flexibility of HT-FSCs is a critical aspect, allowing their application under various deformation conditions such as bending, twisting, compressing and stretching. The deviation of active materials in the electrode and electrolyte from their original positions under different deformation modes impacts the contact between the electrode and electrolyte, consequently influencing the electrochemical performance of the device. To assess the ability of an HT-FSC to withstand or adapt to mechanical deformations, it is subjected to bending at angles ranging from 0 to 180°, twisting at a specific twist angle, stretching under various strain levels, or compression with varying forces. Its electrochemical performance, such as capacitance and resistance before and after deformation, is measured and compared. To simulate real-world scenarios, an FSC device may undergo cycles of deformation-release, and its performance is evaluated before, during, and after each cycle. Sometimes, a charging/discharging cycling test is performed under defined deformation conditions. Extensive efforts have been devoted to maintaining these properties consistently after various deformation cycles, ensuring high electrochemical and mechanical stability. To attain high flexibility of HT-FSCs, some essential aspects need to be considered, such as the selection of flexible electrode materials and substrates, the design of electrolytes that are compatible with flexible materials and can accommodate deformation, the assembly/package of FSCs that prevents damage and maintains the interconnections between different components under repeated deformations, etc. 2.2.3 Thermal characterization The effects of elevated temperatures on FSCs include the following: (i) variation in the properties of GPEs such as ionic conductivity, solubility of salts, and the amount of solvent; (ii) changes in the properties of electrodes like weight of active materials, charge transfer speed, types and amount of active sites; (iii) interactions/reactions between electrode and electrolyte, consequently influencing the overall performance of FSCs. It is known that electrode materials can act as catalysts, promoting decomposition of electrolytes at higher temperature. For example, a rise in temperature was found to boost the oxygen evolution reaction at the positive electrode [24]. The generated volatile and nonvolatile products from the electrolyte systems may further induce surface modification or surface reaction (e.g., oxidation) of electrodes [25], leading to changed structure (e.g., porosity, surface area) and surface chemistry of electrode materials. To examine the effect of temperature on the electrochemical performance (e.g., cell voltage, equivalent series resistance and aging) and the mechanical performance of HT-FSCs, electrochemical and flexibility tests are conducted at different temperatures, and the results are compared. The thermal stability of the components within an HT-FSC, especially the electrodes and GPEs, is a critical factor that directly dictates the operational temperature range of the device. It can be examined using many techniques, such as thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC). TGA is a technique that quantifies the mass changes of a substance in response to temperature variations, either within an air environment or under a protective gas atmosphere. It provides insights into changes in physical and chemical properties of the substance, such as vaporization (e.g., moisture), desolvation/dehydration, oxidation, and decomposition, etc. In a DSC measurement, differences in heat flow required to maintain a sample and a reference material at an identical temperature are recorded as a function of temperature [26]. In other words, as the sample undergoes temperature changes, the variations in heat absorption or release are detected, revealing thermal properties such as crystallization, melting, vaporization, glass transition, and reactions within the material. Other characterization techniques like Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy and Raman spectroscopy, and electrochemical techniques like cyclic voltammetry are useful tools to examine the variations in the compositions of electrodes and electrolytes at elevated temperatures. For example, FTIR spectroscopy could be applied for identification and quantification of components in a mixture. Through the comparison of CVs acquired at different operational temperatures, the appearance of peaks and humps can be employed to deduce possible variations in the composition of substances and surface functional groups. The thermal conductivities of electrode materials and GPEs play important roles in understanding the temperature distribution within electrochemical devices. However, they have not attracted widespread attention, and insufficient research has been conducted on this aspect. According to Eq. (7), materials with higher thermal conductivity transfer heat more effectively, resulting in a reduced temperature gradient under a specific heat flux [27]. (7) q = - λ dT dx where q is the heat flux, λ the thermal conductivity, dT/dx the temperature gradient along the direction of heat transfer. The thermal conductivity of a material can be influenced by many factors, such as composition, structure, and testing conditions (e.g., temperature and pressure). For example, the thermal conductivity of an electrode is dependent on the porosity and morphology of the active electrode material, the fractions/distributions of used binder and conducting agent, the filling of electrolytes in the pores, and the adhesion between the electrode material and the current collector, etc [28,29]. Hence, even with the same material, the thermal conductivity may vary in practical applications, leading to varied thermal behavior of related components and FSCs. The ionic conductivity is another key criterion in the design of GPEs for HT-FSCs, which impacts the electrochemical performance across varying temperatures. Given that GPEs possess comparatively lower ionic conductivity than liquid electrolytes, various strategies have been employed to improve their ionic conductivity. One effective approach is the incorporation of plasticizers into the polymer host to induce amorphous phases, which is beneficial for enhancing ion transport [30]. It is known that the ionic conductivity of GPEs depends mainly on the concentration of charge carriers and their mobility. An elevation in ion concentration contributes to enhanced ionic conductivity. Nevertheless, an excessively high ion concentration may induce ion aggregation and heighten interactions between ions with opposing charges, ultimately leading to reduced ionic conductivity. With rising temperature, the ionic conductivity of GPEs generally increases, a phenomenon attributed to enhanced ion diffusion and improved segmental motion of polymer chains. Additionally, high temperatures can facilitate the penetration of ions into the innermost pores of the electrodes. However, enhanced conductivity at elevated temperatures is often accompanied by an undesired increase in fluidity of GPEs, potentially affecting the reliability of GPEs. At excessively high temperatures, components within GPEs may undergo decomposition, potentially leading to a decline in ionic conductivity. Experimentally, the ionic conductivity of a GPE can be determined by EIS measurements according to following equation [31]. (8) σ = l R b S where σ, l, Rb and S are the ionic conductivity, the thickness, the bulk resistance determined by extracting the intercept on the real axis of a Nyquist plot, and the contact area of a GPE with electrodes, respectively. By acquiring EIS plots at various temperatures, the relationship between ionic conductivity and temperature can be identified. Theoretically, two models are commonly employed to describe the temperature dependence of ionic conductivity, namely the Arrhenius equation (Eq. (9)) and Vogel-Tamman-Fulcher equation (Eq. (10)) [9]. (9) σ = A e x p ( - E a RT ) (10) σ = A T 1 / 2 e x p ( - E a R ( T - T 0 ) where A is the pre-exponential factor, Ea the activation energy, T the absolute temperature, R the ideal gas constant, and T 0 the reference temperature related to the glass transition temperature. The values of A, Ea and T 0 can be determined by fitting experimental results to the models. Due to the diverse and complex structures of GPEs and the complicated ion transport mechanisms within them, experimental results may deviate from the aforementioned models. Creating a fundamental equation or a physical model to describe the temperature dependence of ionic conductivity in GPEs still remains a challenging task. 3 GPEs for HT-FSCs As a key component of HT-FSCs, the designed GPE determines the performance of a device. GPEs should possess the features of high thermal stability and good flexibility. Meanwhile, they should meet the requirements of high ionic conductivity, a wide electrochemical potential window, good interfacial contacts with electrodes, and high chemical and electrochemical stability, to maintain high electrochemical/mechanical performance of FSCs at elevated temperatures. According to the liquid electrolytes contained in GPEs, namely aqueous electrolytes, organic electrolytes and ionic liquids (ILs), GPEs can be divided into hydrogels, organogels and ionogels, respectively [6,32]. Hydrogels show the advantages of convenient operation in air, non-flammability, high safety, low cost and high conductivity superior to organogels and ionogels. However, at high temperatures, water molecules readily undergo evaporation, leading to deteriorated electrochemical performance of hydrogels. Additionally, commonly used hydrogels suffer from a narrow electrochemical potential window because of the relatively low electrochemical stability of water, which has a thermodynamic voltage limit of 1.23 V. This is much lower than that of non-aqueous electrolytes, such as organogels and ionogels, which provide wider electrochemical potential windows of even larger than 3.0 V [33,34]. Such a limitation results in limited energy densities for hydrogel based FSCs. In comparison, ionogels contain ILs that exhibit inherent high viscosity, low conductivity, and limited accessibility to small pores of porous electrode materials, while organogels suffer from safe barriers of high flammability, high volatility and toxicity. The requirement of moisture-free environment during their manufacturing procedure raises dramatically the complexity and price of their fabrication. To take the advantages of different electrolytes, researchers have conducted mixtures of different types of electrolytes, resulting in the formation of new GPEs, such as organohydrogels. To obtain GPEs with good flexibility, high electrochemical performance, and heat resistance, it is important to select suitable electrolytic compounds, solvents, host polymers, and other additives. Several effective strategies have been reported for the synthesis of such GPEs: i) the use of a WIS solution with limited water content to prevent the vaporization and decomposition of water by immobilizing water molecules with salt ions; ii) the formation of ionogels that possess the merits of ILs such as non-volatility, non-flammability and a wide electrochemical window; iii) the incorporation of a mixed solvent that combines the inherent properties of individual solvents with the emergence of new properties resulting from interactions between these solvents; iv) engineering of polymers by using mixed polymers, copolymers and cross-linked polymers to tailor the properties of the host material; v) the incorporation of thermal resistant fillers that interact with both the polymer host and the solvent, resulting in not only improved overall thermal performance but also enhanced ionic conductivity of GPEs. 3.1 WIS-GPEs A fundamental challenge of hydrogels for FSCs operating at high temperatures is the evaporation of large amounts of water molecules, resulting in the deterioration of their electrochemical performance and work durability, thus limiting their practical application in harsh environments. The development of thermally stable hydrogel with feasible engineering strategies is of great importance for addressing these issues. Additionally, efforts have also been spared on enhancing the electrochemical stability of aqueous electrolyte under high voltage currently. The formation of WIS hydrogels has emerged as a highly effective solution to address the concerns mentioned above [35,36]. WIS electrolytes refer to super-concentrated aqueous electrolytes, in which the ratio of salt to water is larger than 1 by volume or weight [37]. The first WIS electrolyte containing 21 m (molality, mol kg−1) lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI) was reported in 2015, which was able to provide a high electrochemical potential window of approximately 3.0 V by using stainless steel as the electrodes [38]. The reason for such a high potential window is the strong coordination of almost all water molecules to metal cations in the solvent-sheath structures. With the high capability of water adsorption and water retention, the electrochemical activity and evaporation of water in WIS electrolytes decrease remarkably. The use of non-flammable and moisture-tolerant WIS electrolytes allows the operation of SCs at enlarged voltage window of beyond 3.0 V and at elevated temperature of up to 120 °C [39]. With the extension of the operating voltage window, comparable to that of non-aqueous electrolytes, significantly enhanced energy densities for energy storage devices are anticipated. The embedding of a WIS electrolyte into a suitable polymer matrix maintains the physicochemical properties of the WIS electrolyte while avoiding potential leakage problems. Some hydrophilic groups or cations in the polymer may also bind to free water molecules and suppress water activity synergistically. Table 1 provides a summary of HT-FSCs based on WIS-GPEs, including their operating voltage windows and temperature tolerances. It can be observed that some HT-FSCs are capable of operating at temperatures even below 0 °C. Note that the reduced performance or failure of SCs at low temperatures may stem from several factors, including slow charge/ion transport kinetics at the electrode/electrolyte interfaces, in the bulk electrolyte and within electrode materials, as well as low ionic conductivity of the electrolyte, salt precipitation due to decreased salt solubility, electrolyte freezing, weakened interaction between the electrolyte and the electrode, and enhanced impedance, etc. [40] In addition, materials that are flexible at room temperature (RT) may become rigid and less pliable in cold conditions, resulting in a reduced capacity for deformation or stretching. Therefore, meeting the requirements for electrolytes and electrode materials to extend the ultra-low-temperature limit involves different considerations compared to extending the ultra-high-temperature limit, which is not within the scope of this review. A WIS-GPE was prepared by mixing a 21 m LiTFSI WIS solution with polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) [41]. Compared to a 1 M (molarity, mol L−1) LiCl-PVA GPE, the 21 m LiTFSI-PVA based WIS-GPE exhibited a sharp Raman peak at 3560 cm−1 of crystalline hydrates that indicated the participation of all water molecules in the Li+ hydration shells, superior water-retention properties at higher temperature of up to 150 °C according to TGA, but relatively lower ionic conductivity. An FSC utilizing the WIS-GPE and carbon cloth (CC) electrodes demonstrated a capacitance of 541.9 mF cm−2 at 1 mA cm−2, an energy density of 243.9 µWh cm−2, and excellent cycling stability during a two-month cycling test (about 15 000 cycles) under environmental conditions. As the operating temperature increased to 80, 100 and 120 °C, its capacitance first increased to 936.4 mF cm−2, then decreased to 525.2 and 531.5 mF cm−2 at 4 mA cm−2, respectively. The decrease in capacitance at higher temperatures was probably due to suppressed directional ion migration, resulting from excessively active ion motion and difficulties in charge transfer at the electrode/electrolyte interfaces associated with elevated temperatures. Nevertheless, the FSC exhibited good cycling performance at high temperatures with capacitance retentions of 80.8% after 100 h (about 500 cycles), 80.1% after 44.1 h, and 79.3% after 12 h at 80, 100, and 120 °C, respectively, demonstrating excellent water-retention capability of the WIS-GPE. Additionally, after twisting the FSC or bending the device to 180° at 120 °C, no significant change was observed on its electrochemical performance. Another symmetric fiber-shaped aqueous FSC constructed by matching N-doped reduced graphene oxide (rGO) fiber electrodes with a WIS-GPE containing 8.96 M LiCl and PVA exhibited a cell voltage of 2.2 V, an energy density of 25.6 μWh cm−2 or 22.7 mWh cm−3, and a capacitance retention of 84% over 20 000 cycles at 3 mA cm−2 at room temperature [44]. The high cell voltage was beneficial from the enlarged water decomposition potential due to the generation of Li+(H2O)n aggregation and the additional water-adsorbing effect of PVA (Fig. 2 a). The FSC demonstrated nearly constant capacitance as the bending angle increased from 0° to 180°. By elevating the operating temperature to 70 °C, the FSC delivered a higher energy density of 36.6 μWh cm−2 (Fig. 2b), whereas the Coulombic efficiency was reduced from approximately 100% to ∼85%, mainly ascribed to the enhanced energy barrier for the desorption of some adsorbed Li+ and Cl− ions from the electrode surface at elevated temperatures. Besides, with the increase in temperature, the decrease in viscosity of the WIS-GPE enhanced ion mobility and mass transport kinetics, resulting in a remarkable decrease in the values of equivalent series resistance (Fig. 2c). One challenge in the formation of a quasi-solid-state WIS-GPE is the capability of polymers to accommodate the ultra-high concentration of salt in the WIS solution to generate a hydrogel with quantified and qualified levels. The in-situ polymerization is a proper solution. For example, in a carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC) substrate solution containing double salts of potassium acrylate (AAK) and CH3COOK, the AAK monomers were in-situ polymerized with the presence of ammonium persulfate (APS) as the initiator and N,N’-methylene bisacrylamide (MBAA) as the cross-linker, leading to the formation of PAAK/CMC-xCH3COOK (x: concentration) hydrogel electrolyte featuring interpenetrating polymer networks between PAAK and CMC chains [45]. The K+ ions in both CH3COOK and PAAK could form solvent-sheath structures by coordinating free water molecules. The potential window of a PAAK/CMC-24 M CH3COOK electrolyte was measured to be 3.1 V at room temperature, higher than those (2.5 and 2.7 V, respectively) of 24 M and 30 M CH3COOK in liquid state, indicating the indispensable role of hydrophilic groups and K+ in the PAAK/CMC polyelectrolyte hydrogel on the inhibition of water activity. Due to the mobility of K+ cations along the charged groups present on the polymer backbones of PAAK and CMC, the WIS-GPE showed a high ionic conductivity of 35.8 mS cm−1, which increased to the value of 70.8 mS cm−1 at 70 °C. The FSC assembled with the combination of the WIS-GPE and N-doped graphene hydrogel electrodes showed excellent temperature adaptability across the range of −20–70 °C. As the temperature rose from −20 °C to 70 °C, the ion diffusion and transport were enhanced, leading to a reduction in the equivalent series resistance and ion transport resistance, and thus resulting in a 31% increase in capacitance. The excellent mechanical properties of the WIS-GPE also enabled high flexibility of the FSC with almost no deformation of CVs or GCD curves under different bending conditions. Another WIS-GPE was formed by irradiation of a mixture including MBAA, 2,2-diethoxyacetophenone, 2-hydroxyethyl methacrylate (HEMA), and a 7 m LiTFSI based WIS solution using an ultraviolet lamp for several minutes [42]. A quasi-solid-state SC constructed using this WIS-GPE and N/S/O co-doped carbon electrodes displayed high temperature robustness within a temperature range of 0–80 °C. After successive charging/discharging tests (10 cycles, 5 A g−1) at each temperature of 0, 20, 40, 60, 80, and 0 °C, the capacitance of the device almost recovered to the initial capacitance at 0 °C. It should be noted that an increase in salt concentration results in an expanded electrochemical potential window for WIS electrolytes. However, it also leads to increased viscosity and decreased conductivity due to the strong electrostatic interaction between cations and anions. These effects can result in sluggish diffusion kinetics and seriously suppressed rate performance of FSCs [47]. The introduction of a water-miscible co-solvent, such as dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), significantly reduces the viscosity and improves the conductivity of WIS electrolytes by reducing cation–anion coupling, while maintaining their wide electrochemical potential window. By controlling the ratio of co-solvent to water, the non-flammability of WIS electrolytes remains. For example, a “DMSO/water in salt”-based chitosan hydrogel electrolyte containing 4 M LiTSFI was synthesized by incorporating an organic co-solvent of DMSO (Fig. 2d). With the eutectic nature of DMSO and water, the GPE showed a conductivity of 10.6 mS cm−1 even at −20 °C, a potential window of 3.0 V and a wide range of operation temperature (−20–70 °C) [43]. The related FSC employing N-doped graphene hydrogel electrodes could operate within a working voltage of 2.1 V, which showed a 140% increase of the discharging time at 1 A g−1 and a 71% decrease of the charge-transfer resistance, as the temperature raised from 0 to 70 °C. An alternative strategy to achieve high conductivity of a WIS-GEL is the implantation of 3D ion channels within the hydrogel matrix. These channels facilitate the transport of ions along their lengths, thus enabling fast ion migration. In a polyacrylamide (PAAm)/chitosan-based hydrogel electrolyte containing LiTFSI, most of the water molecules were retained by abundant hydroxyl and amino groups on the hydrogel 3D network, forming polar coronas and 3D channels for the fast transport of Li+ in an unsaturated coordination state [48]. This GPE provided an electrochemical potential window of 2.6 V and a high ionic conductivity of 51.3 mS cm−1 that was five times of that of a 21 M LiTFSI based liquid WIS electrolyte. To further improve the performance of WIS-GPE based FSCs, advanced FSCs like metal-ion FSCs and redox-electrolyte enhanced FSCs have been constructed. A zinc-ion FSC ( Fig. 2 e) was assembled using N/P-doped rGO and Zn foil as the cathode and anode, respectively, sandwiched with the PAAK/sodium carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC-Na) hydrogel electrolyte containing 1 M Zn(CH3COO)2 and 20 M CH3COOK). It demonstrated a high energy density of 106.5 W h kg−1 at a power density of 383.3 W kg−1, a capacitance retention of 86.6% with a Coulombic efficiency of nearly 100% after 8 000 cycles at 5 A g−1, a good flexibility with nearly no loss of capacitance even under 180° bending condition ( Fig. 2 f) and a good temperature tolerance between −15–65 °C ( Fig. 2 g) [46]. The introduction of redox-active species in WIS electrolytes, which undergo redox reactions at the interface between the electrode and the electrolyte during charging/discharging processes, brings additional capacitance [49–52]. For example, the introduction of 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium iodide (BMIM·I) in a 10 m LiTFSI/PVA WIS hydrogel electrolyte led to an increase of the electrode specific capacitance from 174.4 to 237.2 F g−1 at 0.5 A g−1, and enhanced conductivity from 15.8 to 27.2 mS cm−1 [52]. However, the change of the performance of such redox-electrolyte enhanced FSCs at elevated temperatures has not been reported yet, and their adaptability under high temperature conditions still needs to be studied. 3.2 Ionic liquid GPEs As room temperature molten salts, ILs comprise entirely of cations and anions. They show general properties of high thermal and chemical stability, high electrochemical stability with a large voltage window, non-flammability and non-volatility with very low vapor pressure [53,54]. By encapsulating ILs within polymer matrices, IL-GPEs or ionogels are formed, which preserve the distinctive characteristics of ILs while simultaneously prevent leakage issues [55]. Three methods have been frequently utilized, namely direct mixing, in-situ polymerization, and solvent substitution [56]. Directly mixing an IL with a polymer network represents the simplest preparation method, however, the compatibility/miscibility issues between ILs and commercially available polymers (e.g., PVA) can impose limitations on the preparation process and may occasionally result in low IL content in ionogels. In-situ gelation of monomers or polymers in ILs can be achieved using various techniques such as thermal or UV-curing free radical polymerization and ring opening polymerization. Solvent exchange becomes an efficient strategy for preparing ionogels when monomers are insoluble or when complex gelation reactions are unattainable in ILs. This process involves replacing the solvents present in related hydrogels or organogels with ILs. The thermal stability of ionogels is highly dependent on the compatibility between ILs and polymers. Nevertheless, various ionogels have been reported to be thermally stable across a broad temperature range exceeding 200 °C [57,58]. The high thermal stability, non-flammability and negligible vapor of ionogels allow ionogel-based FSCs to function efficiently even at high temperatures. Table 2 summarizes the reported HT-FSCs based on IL-GPEs. An alginate-based ionogel containing 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate (EMIM·BF4) was thermally stable up to 280 °C. The corresponding FSC formed by sandwiched assembly method of activated carbon fiber cloth electrode/ionogel/activated carbon fiber cloth electrode was electrochemically stable under a high voltage of 3.5 V and at a high operating temperature of 60 °C [68]. A planar on-chip Li-ion micro-SC was assembled using carbon-coated Li4Ti5O12 nanospheres as the anode, activated graphene as the cathode, and an ionogel composed of LiTFSI, 1-butyl-1-methylpyrrolidinium bis(trifluoromethyl-sulfonyl)imide (P14TFSI) and poly(vinylidene fluoride-co-hexafluoropropylene) (PVDF-HFP) as the electrolyte [82]. Under different bending angles ranging from 0 to 180° and larger than 180° (in state of a circle shape), the FSC showed overlapped CVs and GCD curves. Almost no degradation and a slight reduction of the initial capacitance were found on the FSCs after 1 000 charging/discharging cycles at a high bending state of a circle, and after 2 000 times of concave and convex bending, respectively, both indicating the exceptional mechanical flexibility of the FSC. With the use of the high-voltage and highly thermally stable ionogel electrolyte, the FSC delivered high volumetric energy densities of 53.5 mW h cm−3 at room temperature and 54.6 mW h cm−3 at 80 °C. It was also observed that the capacitance and rate capability of the FSC both improved as the temperature increased from 25 to 80 °C, originated from the decreased viscosity, accelerated ion diffusion rate and thus increased ionic conductivity (from 0.8 to 3.3 mS cm−1) of the ionogel. At the operation temperature of 80 °C, the FSC showed a high cycling stability, with 88% capacitance retention and nearly 100% Coulombic efficiency after 2 000 cycles at 1 mA cm−2. Another Li-ion FSC was constructed using core–shell TiNb2O7@MoS2/C as the cathode, AC as the anode, and an ionogel composed of PVDF-HFP, 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl)imide (EMIM·TFSI), LITFSI, and SiO2 particles as the gel electrolyte [72]. The employment of the ionogel allowed the operation of the FSC at a wide cell voltage of 4.0 V and the achievement of impressed electrochemical performance at a high temperature of 60 °C, with a capacitance of 68.3 F g−1 at 1 A g−1, a maximal energy density of 147.2 W h kg−1 at a power density of 2470.5 W kg−1, and a maximum power density of 21856.3 W kg−1 at an energy density of 77.1 W h kg−1. An ionogel was prepared by mixing EMIM·BF4, bis(trifluoromethane) sulfonimide sodium (NaTFSI), and PVDF-HFP, which was then utilized for the construction of sodium-ion quasi-solid-state SC based on MoS2/CNT anode and AC cathode [71]. Under an operating temperature of 70 °C, it delivered a maximal energy density of 115.7 W h kg−1 at a power density 2090.9 W kg−1, which still reached 80 W h kg−1 at a maximal power density of 22668.7 W kg−1. Another sodium-ion FSC was assembled, utilizing urchin-like sodium titanate as the faradaic anode, nanoporous activated graphene as the non-faradaic cathode, and an ionogel composed of NaTFSI, P14TFSI and PVDF-HFP as the electrolyte [83]. It demonstrated a broad working voltage window of 3.5 V, a high energy density of 37.1 mWh cm−3, a low self-discharging rate with a self-discharging time of 44 h from V max (3.5 V) to 0.6 V max, and a capacitance retention of 75% after 6 000 cycles at 0.8 mA cm−2. The device maintained nearly constant capacitance across various bending conditions (from 0 to 180° bending angles and in a circular state) and throughout 2 000 bending cycles at 180°. As the operation temperature rose from room temperature to 80 °C, the device preserved a similar shape in its GCD curves, while the capacitance increased from 11.8 to 14.6 mF cm−2 at 0.3 mA cm−2, due to enhanced ionic conductivity of the ionogel from 0.5 to 2.8 mS cm−1. One challenge remains in ionogels is that their ionic conductivity is found to be only 30% to 50% of that exhibited by pure ILs [84]. The increase of IL content is one solution to solve this problem, yet this approach may concurrently lead to a reduction in the mechanical strength of ionogels. Since the primary cause of lower ionic conductivity in ionogels is the restricted mobility of IL ions due to their immobilization within a polymer host, researches have been focused on the enhancement of ionic mobility. Possible ways are the introduction of solid or liquid solvents (e.g., succinonitrile (SN) [60,69]) with polar nature to dissociate the ionic salts, the addition of inorganic fillers (e.g., SiO2 [73,76], montmorillonite (MMT) [59], halloysite nanotubes (HNTs) [77], and MXene [80]), the design of morphology and structure of ionogels to generate extra ion diffusion pathways, and the in-situ embedding of ILs during polymerization and cross-linking processes. The incorporation of SN in an ionogel prepared using PVDF-HFP copolymer as the host polymer and 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate (BMIM·BF4) as the ionic salt led to good ionic conductivity of the ionogel across a broad temperature range, ranging from 0.5 mS cm−1 at −30 °C to 15 mS cm−1 at 80 °C, which was nearly one order of magnitude larger than those obtained on the ionogel without SN [60]. The related FSC based on AC electrodes could be operated at 80 °C with a wide cell voltage of 2.5 V. Another FSC, based on an ionogel prepared by entrapping SN and EMIM·BF4 in PVDF-HFP and B, N-doped CNT/carbon fiber electrodes, showed good flexibility under bending angles of 0–90°, a broad cell voltage of 3.0 V, and good electrochemical performance at 100 °C (an energy density of 2.25 mWh cm−3 at 1 mA cm−2 and a capacitance retention of 86.1% after 200 cycles at 5 mA cm−2) (Fig. 3 a–e) [69]. For the preparation of a chitosan and 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium acetate (EMIM·OAc) based ionogel, the inclusion of γ-Valerolactone organic solvent in EMIM·OAc resulted in several beneficial effects, including a reduction in viscosity and an increase in the ionic conductivity of the IL, as well as an enhancement in the solubility of chitosan. The further introduction of SiO2 nanoparticles resulted in the simultaneous enhancement of the mechanical performance and ionic conductivity of the gel, due to increased hydrogen bonding interactions between the silanol groups (Si–OH) on the SiO2 surfaces and the amino/hydroxyl groups on the chitosan chains. These interactions not only facilitated the formation of continuous and highly conductive ion transport channels but also promoted energy dissipation. This ionogel showed high ionic conductivities of 24.3 and 60.3 mS cm−1 at 25 and 80 °C, respectively [76]. The related quasi-solid-state SC using AC electrodes displayed good capacitive performance at a high temperature of up to 80 °C, namely a capacitance of 113.2 F g−1 at 0.1 A g−1 and a capacitance retention of 92.3% at 2 A g− 1 after 10 000 cycles, which were 84.6 F g−1 and 100% at 25 °C under the same test parameters, respectively. The production of ionogels with ordered structures has been reported to improve their ion transport ability. An aligned ionogel was prepared using an ice-templating method, accompanied with the self-initiated cryopolymerization of N,N-dimethylacrylamide (DMAA) in the presence of TiO2 nanoparticles and clay nanosheets, and followed by the solvent replacement of water with BMIM·BF4 [62]. X-ray computed tomography (XCT) was used to investigate the microstructures of the aligned and nonaligned ionogel structures, as the basis for further 3D diffusion simulations (Fig. 3f). Unlike the nonaligned structure possessing isotropic transport properties, the diffusion simulations indicated that the diffusion in the aligned system with layered structure was highly anisotropic, in which the diffusivity could be varied by an order of magnitude depending on the direction. In the aligned direction, the aligned GPE provided superior ionic conductivity as compared to nonaligned ionogel. Therefore, the FSC based on the ionogel with aligned pore structures showed better electrochemical performance than the nonaligned ionogel based device in a wide operating temperature range of 25–200 °C (Fig. 3g–i). Additionally, as the temperature increased from 25 to 200 °C, a 530% increase, an 87% decrease and a 108% increase in ionic conductivity and viscosity of the aligned ionogel, and specific capacitance of the related FSC were observed, respectively. The selection of suitable ILs that can cross-link or strongly interact with polymer matrices during in-situ polymerization can concurrently improve the ionic conductivity and mechanical strength of the formed GPEs [79,80]. In an ionogel containing a PAAm network and ILs of EMIM·TFSI and 1-vinyl-3-methylimidazolium bis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl)imide (VMIM·TFSI), VMIM·TFSI acted as a cross-linking agent during the in-situ polymerization of acrylamide (AAm), leading to the formation of a cross-linked network structure with improved ionic conductivity and thermal stability [79]. The ionogel showed a remarkable ionic conductivity of 23 mS cm−1 at 90 °C that persisted at 71% even after being placed at room temperature for 20 days, high thermal stability with a thermal decomposition temperature of higher than 200 °C, and good mechanical properties with 1300% elongation at break. The FSC constructed with the combination of the ionogel and poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) (PEDOT)/CC electrodes possessed almost overlapped CVs at different temperatures ranging from 0 to 90 °C, indicating its availability and good electrochemical performance at high temperatures. It is also necessary to increase the mechanical performance of ionogels to reduce or eliminate the degradation of electrochemical performance during mechanical deformations like bending, compressing or stretching. Some approaches have been reported, such as the use of double polymer networks containing one soft polymer [67], the combination with scaffolds of high porosity and high mechanical strength [61], and the introduction of fillers with high mechanical strength [77], etc. For example, a low-cost porous facial cotton mask membrane with good liquid retention ability was combined with an ionogel composed of in-situ photopolymerized poly(N, N-dimethylacrylamide) (PDMAA)/BMIM·BF4 to form an ionogel-in-mask hybrid gel electrolyte (Fig. 4 a–e) [61]. The cellulose molecules and hydroxyl groups contained in the cotton mask could provide supramolecular effects between the mask substance and the ionogel. As a result, the hybrid gel electrolyte combined the mechanical advantages of the mask and the electrochemical and thermal characteristics of the ionogel (Fig. 4f, g). The related FSC using AC electrodes functioned well at temperature ranging from 25 to 200 °C with the change of capacitance from 26 to 160 F g−1 at a high current density of 15 A g−1 (Fig. 4h, i). 3.3 GPEs with mixed solvents Mixed solvents possessing integrated properties of the individual components have been employed in GPEs. By adjusting the type and ratio of mixed solvents, the properties of the electrolytes (e.g., ionic conductivity, viscosity, electrochemical potential window, solubility of ionic species, temperature-dependent behavior, and compatibility with electrode materials) could be tailored to meet the requirements of a particular application. For example, the introduction of organic solvents into hydrogels allows the operation of the gel electrolytes in a wider potential window and an extended temperature range, while the addition of organic solvents in ionogels leads to reduced viscosity and increased ion mobility. Organohydrogels are one frequently reported kind of GPEs containing a mixed solvent system of water and organic solvents like glycerol (GLY), DMSO and ethylene glycol (EG). They can be fabricated either by gel formation of a liquid system containing mixed solvents or by solvent replacement following the gel formation of an aqueous solution. The presence of water-miscible organic solvents leads to the generation of H-bond interactions between organic solvents and water, resulting in the reduction of free water molecule amount, and the suppression of water evaporation and splitting reactions [85,86]. Furthermore, these organic solvents also possess the ability of ion transportation, which is beneficial in mitigating the reduction in ionic conductivity and performance degradation caused by water evaporation at elevated temperatures. The reported HT-FSCs based on organohydrogel electrolyte are summarized in Table 3 . The cell voltages of these HT-FSCs vary in a wide range of 0.6 to 2.4 V. Note that the voltage window of a device is dependent on the electrode/electrolyte systems and the configuration of FSCs. Pseudocapacitive materials, such as conducting polymers, typically exhibit a lower potential window compared to carbon materials, while changes in the surface functional groups of carbon materials can also lead to variations in their potential windows [16,87]. Besides, an asymmetric FSC could deliver a high cell voltage because of the different potential windows of the cathodic and anodic electrode/electrolyte systems [19,88]. Additionally, other factors, such as the nature of organic solvents, the sensibility of the system to water, the interaction between electrode materials and the electrolyte, can impact the operating voltage of an FSC. With the addition of suitable amount of GLY in an LiTFSI aqueous solution, the formed organohydrogel using PVA as the gel-forming agent achieved an electrochemical potential window of 3.0 V (vs. Ag/AgCl), despite the low concentration of LiTFSI (2 m) [89]. This was measured using the linear sweep voltammetry technique on a three-electrode system with CNT sponge, Pt plate and a standard Ag/AgCl electrode as the working, counter and reference electrodes, respectively. Such a high potential window was due to the formation of intermolecular hydrogen bonds of water with GLY molecules and PVA, resulting in negligible amount of free water (Fig. 5 a). The FSC assembled using this organohydrogel sandwiched between two CNT sponge-based electrodes showed little variation in the specific capacitance as the temperature increased from −20 to 60 °C (Fig. 5b, c). An organohydrogel electrolyte containing a binary solvent system of EG/H2O (v: v = 9:1), ZnCl2/NH4Cl salts, and a poly(2-acrylamido-2-methylpropane sulfonic acid) (PAMPS)/PAAm double-network polymer matrix was used for the fabrication of a zinc-ion FSC. The used cathode and anode materials were CC and zinc foil, respectively. The addition of EG could alter the solvation sheath structure of Zn2+ with water molecules due to its strong affinity with Zn2+, which in turn improved the wettability of the electrolyte to Zn anode. Furthermore, EG acted as a ‘water blocker’ to inhibit hydrolysis and prevented the formation of zinc dendrites [92]. The FSC exhibited nearly unchanged capacitance under bent states with different bending angles of 0–180° and under external weight loads of 1.0–4.0 kg. The FSC showed broad temperature adaptability in the range of −30 to 80 °C. Its capacitance retention at 80 °C reached 88.6% after 12 000 cycles at 5 A g−1. Another symmetric FSC was assembled using AC electrodes and an organohydrogel electrolyte, which was prepared by the formation of a double-network hydrogel of PAMPS/PAAm followed by soaking in a 4 M LiCl/EG solution to replace water in the hydrogel [93]. With the high boiling point of EG (197.3 °C), the hydrogen bonding between water and EG molecules, and the ionic hydration effect of Li+, the FSC exhibited a broad temperature adaptability ranging from −20 to 80 °C (Fig. 5d). The capacitance of the FSC being placed at 80 °C for 56 h still remained 77.3% of the initial value (Fig. 5e). Additionally, the capacitance retention of the FSC after 10 000 cycles at 5 A g−1 and 80 °C was 91.3%. However, when using a PAMPS/PAAm-based hydrogel immersed with LiCl aqueous solution instead of LiCl/EG, the capacitance retention dropped to only 18.8% after 1 000 cycles under the same conditions (Fig. 5f). This was because of the evaporation of water from the hydrogel, leading to severe volume shrinkage and structure damage of the device. In contrast, an almost identical appearance with only a mild reduction in thickness was observed in the organohydrogel (Fig. 5g). Interestingly, other salts (e.g., LiClO4, NaCl, and KCl) that possessed good solubility in EG could also be applied for the construction of such organohydrogels to be used in FSCs for high temperature operation. DMSO possesses the features of high boiling point, good chemical stability, strong polarity, and remarkable hydrogen-bond affinity to water molecules. These properties enable the binary mixture of DMSO and water to exhibit low freezing point and high thermal stability [106,107,109]. An FSC was fabricated by using CNT/PANI electrodes and an organohydrogel electrolyte containing 2-acrylamido-2-methylpropane sulfonic acid (AMPS) and AAm copolymerized polymer host, H2O/DMSO binary solvent and LiCl salt. It could work within a wide temperature range of −20–100 °C, mainly due to the presence of abundant hydrogen bonds formed among DMSO, water molecules and functional groups of polymer molecules [102]. It showed a capacitance retention of 85% at 100 °C, comparable to that obtained at room temperature. Moreover, almost no changes in capacitance were observed after multiple heating–cooling-heating cycles ranging from −20 °C to 100 °C. The amount of DMSO added to the organohydrogel also affected the thermal and electrochemical performance of FSCs. At low DMSO concentrations, there were few DMSO molecules available to interact with water molecules and polymer chains, resulting in insufficient hydrogen bonding. Conversely, at high DMSO concentrations, dimers were formed. DESs represent a novel class of solvents prepared by the eutectic mixture of at least two components, typically including a hydrogen bond acceptor and a hydrogen bond donor [110,111]. The melting point of a DES is significantly lower than that of each of its individual components. DESs exhibit physical and chemical characteristics similar to ILs, such as low volatility, wide electrochemical potential windows, high thermal and chemical stability [112]. Additionally, DESs offer the advantages of low toxicity, facile preparation and low cost. A eutectogel is formed by immobilizing DES in a polymer host. It has been applied for the development of HT-FSCs (Table 4 ). Compared to ionogel based HT-FSCs, the upper operation temperature limits of eutectogel based HT-FSCs are relatively lower. One possible reason is the liberation of effective constituents from DESs (e.g., EG from choline chloride/EG), leading to a decrease in thermal stability [113,114]. For the construction of HT-FSCs, a eutectogel was prepared by in-situ polymerization of acrylic acid (AA) and AAm monomers in a LiClO4-urea-H2O ternary DES [115]. The corresponding FSC using AC electrodes demonstrated a stable voltage window of 0–2.0 V, a moderate bendability (0 – 90°) and a wide operating temperature range of −40–60 °C. Choline chloride has been frequently used as a hydrogen bond acceptor for the formation of DESs. A choline chloride-GLY DES based eutectogel was synthesized via in-situ polymerization of AA [116], while a choline chloride-EG based eutectogel was formed by free-radical copolymerization of AA and sulfobetaine vinylimidazole (VIPS) [113]. By using AC as electrodes, the FSCs constructed using the aforementioned eutectogels both demonstrated wide-temperature adaptability, ranging from −20 to 80 °C. Another wide-temperature-tolerant eutectogel, with a working range of −40 to 60 °C, was developed by immersing a pre-fabricated hydrogel based on sulfonated poly(ether-ether-ketone) (SPEEK) and PAAm into a ternary DES [117]. The DES was prepared by dissolving Zn(ClO4)2⋅6H2O in EG, using Zn(ClO4)2 as the hydrogen bond acceptor, and EG and H2O as the hydrogen bond donors. A Zn-ion FSC was assembled by sandwiching the eutectogel between a Zn anode and an AC cathode. It could deliver a specific capacitance of 143.41 F g−1 in a voltage window of 0.2–1.9 V at 0.5 A g−1 at 60 °C, about 24.2% higher than that obtained at 20 °C. Moreover, it still functioned well under various harsh conditions, such as bending, compressing, puncturing, and cutting. With the presence of polymerizable component(s) in a DES, a eutectogel could be obtained by in-situ polymerization of the DES system. In a Zn(ClO4)2-AAm-H2O ternary DES, ClO4 − initiated and accelerated the free-radical polymerization of AAm monomer and Zn2+ cross-linked the polymer chains ( Fig. 6 a) [118]. The eutectogel exhibited a three-dimensional network structure, as confirmed by its SEM image ( Fig. 6b). The eutectogel was then used as the electrolyte to form Zn-ion FSC based on Zn anode and N doped-rGO cathode. The FSC possessed a large steady cell voltage of 2.2 V, a high energy density of 117.5 W h kg−1 at a power density of 833.8 W kg−1, remarkable thermal stability within a temperature range of −20–70 °C ( Fig. 6c). After adding a photoinitiator (2,2-diethoxyacetophenone) and H2SO4 in a DES consisted of urea and polymerizable 3-acrylamidopropyl trimethylammonium chloride (ATAC), polymerization of ATAC was triggered by UV irradiation and an eutectogel was formed [119]. The eutectogel showed unchanged mass and stable ionic conductivity (about 11.92 mS cm−1) within 7 days under a high temperature of 60 °C. A corresponding FSC was fabricated using PANI eutectogel electrodes, which was prepared by in-situ polymerization of aniline in a solution with dispersed eutectogel. The FSC delivered a specific capacitance of 31.3 mF cm−2 at 0.5 mA cm−2 at 60 °C, higher than that (24.9 mF cm−2 at 0.05 mA cm−2) obtained at 25 °C, mainly due to increased ionic conductivity of the eutectogel at higher temperature. It also demonstrated excellent self-healing ability (94.6 % capacitance retention after 5 cutting-healing cycles), high stretchability (beyond 200 %), and extraordinary bendability (86.7 % capacitance retention after 2 000 cycles at the bending angle of 180°). 3.4 Engineering of polymeric frameworks A common and simple method to prepare GPEs is the mixture of common polymer matrices like poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO) and PVA with related liquid solutions. However, such GPEs may suffer from several disadvantages, such as relatively low ionic conductivity, restricted salt solubility, lack of mechanical strength, moderate compatibility with electrode materials, and limited electrochemical and thermal stability. It should be pointed out that a good polymeric framework for GPEs to be used in HT-FSCs with high performance should possess the features of rich functional groups interacting with other components in GPEs, good ion diffusion ability, stretchable molecular chains and high decomposition temperatures. To meet these requirements, various approaches (e.g., in-situ polymerization, copolymerization, polymer/polymerization cross-linking) have been developed to prepare novel polymer hosts. By mixing boric acid in GLY containing KOH, the three hydroxyl groups in boric acid coordinated with the three hydroxyl groups of GLY, forming a three-dimensional network structure, which was in quasi-solid-state and non-flammable [120]. The related FSC constructed by combining this organogel with AC electrodes was capable to be operated at a wide temperature range of 0–80 °C. With increasing temperature, the area of recorded CVs increased continually, indicating enhanced capacitance of the device, whereas the resistivity values decreased. A copolymer is a polymer composed of two or more different monomers that are chemically linked together within the same polymer chain. It integrates the specific properties of individual monomers. In a eutectogel consisting of choline chloride-EG DES and copolymerized poly(AA-co-VIPS), the change of monomer molar ratio (AA: VIPS) and copolymer content led to changed mechanical properties and ionic conductivity of the gel [113]. As the content of VIPS in copolymer increased, the fracture strain, tensile strength and elastic modulus of the gel first increased and then decreased. Further increase of copolymer content from 25 to 45 wt% resulted in significantly increasement of the tensile strength (from 28 to 176 kPa), fracture strain (from 720% to 1370%) and ionic conductivity (from 2.7 to 4.1 mS cm−1). A poly(acrylic acid-co-1-vinylimidazole) (P(AA-co-VI)) ionogel was prepared by in-situ copolymerization of AA and 1-vinylimidazole monomers in 1-buty-3-methylimidazolium chloride (BMIM·Cl) in the presence of PEGDA as the chemical cross-linker [64]. Due to the dense interpolymer hydrogen bonds generated between the imidazole and carboxylic acid groups in the hybrid cross-linked network, the P(AA-co-VI)/BMIM·Cl ionogel showed better mechanical properties (e.g., strength, stretchability, toughness), higher ionic conductivity, and higher thermal stability with a higher decomposition temperature, compared to poly(acrylic acid) (PAA)/BMIM·Cl ionogel. As the operating temperature increased from 25 to 150 °C, the FSC constructed using the P(AA-co-VI) ionogel and AC based electrodes showed increasingly rectangular shaped CVs, decreased equivalent series resistance from 22.3 to 5.6 Ω, and increased capacitance from 82.9 to 379.6 F g−1. In another work, 1-vinyl-3-butylimidazole bromide (VBIM·Br) was copolymerized with AAm by cleavage of CC bonds in AAm monomer and further connection of these bonds with CC bonds in VBIM·Br (Fig. 7 a) [121]. The poly(VBIMBr-co-AAm) chains was then cross-linked with MBAA to generate a hydrogel with 3D network. It showed winkled structure, which turned to porous structure with pore size of about 10–20 μm after freeze dried treatment (Fig. 7b, c). The FSC formed by assembling poly(VBIMBr-co-AAm) hydrogel with AC electrodes showed the characteristics of thermal resistance (−20–50 °C), acid and alkali resistance (pH1–pH13) and bending resistance (0–150°). Double network GPEs consisted of two networks of different properties have been reported. With the synergic advantages of both networks, high ionic conductivity and high mechanical, thermal and electrochemical stability of GPEs are able to be achieved simultaneously. The two networks suitable for HT-FSCs could be two organic polymer networks such as PVA/poly(AAm-co-VBIPS) [70], PVA/cellulosic poly(protic ILs) [122], PVA/starch [104], PVA/agar [123], PVA/poly(HEMA) (PHEMA) [67], PVA/polyimide [103], PVA/PAAm/chitosan [91], PAAm/chitosan [124], PAAm/carboxylated chitosan (CCS) [90], PAAm/cellulose [125], PAAm/carrageenan [126], PAAm/alginate [107,127], PAAm/gelatine, PAAm/PAMPS [92,93,95], PAAm/SPEEK [117], PAAm/PAA [36,115], PHEMA/phosphorylated cellulose [81], PHEMA/chitosan [65], or the combination of an organic network with an inorganic network, like PHEMA/silica network [63]. An organohydrogel with CCS/PAAm double-network was successfully synthesized by polymerizing AAm with the presence of CCS, as confirmed by the spectra obtained on FTIR spectroscopy (Fig. 7d) [90]. Compared to PAAm organohydrogel with few pores and CCS organohydrogel with almost no pores, the CCS/PAAm organohydrogel exhibited many pores as paths for ion transport (Fig. 7e–g). The CCS/PAAm organohydrogel also possessed higher tensile strength elongation (Fig. 7h). The related FSC based on AC electrodes was able to be operated at a wide temperature range of −11–70 °C (Fig. 7i). In a double-network hydrogel composed of H3PO4/H2O acid electrolyte and chemically cross-linked PAAm/chitosan, the PAAm network endowed antifreeze and heat resistance, while chitosan improved mechanical flexibility and adhesive performance of the hydrogel [124]. The FSC constructed by coupling the hydrogel with AC electrodes demonstrated excellent flexibility and a wide range of temperature tolerance (−60–100 °C). Another FSC constructed using AC electrodes and PAMPS/PAAm double-network based organohydrogel demonstrated excellent mechanical toughness, mainly due to the friction and dynamic interaction between the two polymer networks, promoting energy dissipation under external stress [93]. During the pressure test (3 kg and about 100 kg) and the bending test (0–180°) of the FSC, the obtained CVs coincided with the initial one. The introduction of chitosan in an ionogel composed of 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride (BMIM·Cl) and in-situ photopolymerized PHEMA led to a significantly enhanced mechanical strength, reduced gelation time, but remained thermal stability (a mass lost less than 3.5% by heating the gel from room temperature to 220 °C according to TGA) and similar ionic conductivity (31–81 mS cm−1 at 80–200 °C) [65]. An ionogel containing two independent and entangled polymer networks of cellulose and PHEMA was synthesized by dissolving and phosphorylating of cellulose in an IL mixture of 1,3-dimethylimidazolium methyl phosphite (DMIM·(MeO)(H)PO3) and 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium bis(tri-fluoromethylsulfonyl)imide (BMIM·TFSI), followed by in-situ polymerization of HEMA [81]. The highly cross-linked PHEMA network and cellulose network were responsible for the high stiffness and stretchability of the ionogel, respectively. They also interacted with each other via hydrogen bonding and chain entanglement. This ionogel showed a high ionic conductivity of 2.6–22.4 mS cm−1 at 30–120 °C and a maximal toughness of 1.46 MJ m−3 at 30 °C. An FSC was constructed by sandwiching the ionogel between two identical AC electrodes. Under an operating temperature of 120 °C, it showed a wide cell voltage of 2.5 V, a high capacitance of 174 F g−1 at 0.5 A g−1, a high-rate capability of 88% from 0.5 to 5 A g−1, a maximal energy density of 38 W h kg−1, a maximal power density of 4.5 kW kg−1, and a capacitance retention of 93% after 10,000 charging/discharging cycles at 2 A g−1. Another FSC was constructed using rGO electrodes and an ionogel prepared by confining EMIM·BF4 in a chemically coupled double network of cross-linked PVA and cross-linked PHEMA ( Fig. 8 a) [67]. It showed high performance under varied operating temperatures from 30 to 180 °C with a cell voltage of 2.0 V ( Fig. 8b, c). As the temperature increased from 30 to 180 °C, the capacitance at 0.1 A g−1, the maximal energy and power densities enhanced from 31 F g−1, 17.2 W h kg−1, 13.1 kW kg−1 to the values of 88 F g−1, 51.0 W h kg−1, 18.8 kW kg−1, respectively. At 150 °C and 1 A g−1, the capacitance retentions were found to be nearly 90% and 91% after consecutive bending for 100 cycles at each angle of 180°, 90°, 60°, 90°, 180° (Fig. 8d), and after 100 000 charging/discharging cycles (Fig. 8e), respectively, indicating good tolerance of the FSC for high-temperature flexible operations. Moreover, the self-discharging behavior of the FSC at different temperatures was evaluated by measuring the open circuit voltage as a function of discharging time. The half-discharging time consumed for dropping from V max (2.0 V) to ½V max (1.0 V) was reduced from ∼50 h at 30 °C to ∼21 h at 180 °C (Fig. 8f). An inorganic–organic double network ionogel containing a brittle first network of self-aggregated silica network and a ductile second network of in-situ polymerized PHEMA was prepared, in which BMIM·BF4 was confined [63]. Due to the synergistic effect of the inorganic and organic networks, the ionogel showed a good ionic conductivity of 3.8 to 12.8 mS cm−1 at temperatures ranging from 30 to 150 °C and a maximum toughness of 1.8 MJ m−3 at 30 °C. The corresponding FSC using rGO based electrodes could be operated at 30–150 °C. Its capacitance at 1 A g−1, maximal energy and power densities reached the values of 52 F g−1, 48 W h kg−1 and 4.0 kW kg−1, respectively, at 150 °C, because of the fast ion transport at high temperature. Besides, the FSC exhibited excellent electrochemical durability under mechanical stress (∼99% capacitance retention after 50 bending from 180 to 120°) and thermal stress (93% capacitance retention after 10 000 charging/discharging cycles at 120 °C). Cross-linking strategies, especially chemical cross-linking of polymer chains have been proposed in recent years to further improve the ionic conductivity, thermo-mechanical properties of GPEs. A chemically cross-linked ionogel based on natural biopolymers of chitosan and cellulose and an IL of 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium acetate (EMIM·Ac) was synthesized via a two-step method, namely the modification of aldehyde functionality on cellulose through periodate oxidized aldehydes reactions in the IL and the formation of cross-linked aldehyde cellulose – chitosan through Schiff-base reaction (Fig. 9 a) [74]. The reversible covalent Schiff-base cross-linkers endowed the ionogel with good thermo-mechanical properties and good self-healing capabilities. Additionally, the ionogel possessed porous microstructure with rough surface (Fig. 9b and c), providing extra ion transport channels and thus leading to high ionic conductivity. The FSC functioned well over a wide temperature range of 25–125 °C and at various bending angles (90° and 180°) (Fig. 9d and e). In another study, methylglyoxal was added as a cross-linking agent in a gelatin/EMIM·Ac IL solution to initiate the Schiff-base reaction for the preparation of a chemically cross-linked ionogel with covalent bonds [75]. The chemical network of the ionogel remained undestroyed even at a high temperature of 140 °C, indicating good thermo-mechanical stability of the GPE, allowing the operation of the related FSC based on AC electrodes under high temperatures of up to 115 °C. For an FSC assembled using AC electrodes and an ionogel of EMIM·BF4 entrapped in poly(ethylene glycol dimethacrylayte) (PEGDMA) matrix, the cross-linking of PEGDMA allowed the operation of the FSC at a high temperature up to 150 °C with good electrochemical performance (a high capacitance of 134 F g−1 at 2 mA cm−2, a high energy density of 41.9 W h kg−1, a high power density of 8.2 kW kg−1, and good stability with a capacitance retention of 83% after 1 000 charging/discharging cycles at 10 mA cm−2) [66]. By grafting polybenzimidazole (PBI) with 3-(triethoxysilyl) propyl isocyanate (IPTS), cross-linked PBI containing a cage-like structure from the siloxane end groups in IPTS was formed [128]. The SiOSi cage-like structure could prevent the leakage of phosphoric acid, leading to higher retention of phosphoric acid (75%) compared to that (50%) using un-crosslinked PBI after 10 days at 80 °C and 40% relative humidity. The FSC packaged using the cross-linked PBI based GPE and AC electrodes achieved a specific capacitance of 314 mF cm−2 at 0.1 A g−1 and a capacitance retention of 85.6% after 1 000 charging/discharging cycles at a high temperature of 150 °C. It also showed good mechanical stability with a 10.3% loss of the initial capacitance after 500 bends at 180°. 3.5 Addition of fillers The addition of heat-resistant fillers with small size into polymer backbones is another effective for enhancing thermal stability of GPEs. Various fillers such as carbon materials, clays, ceramic fillers (e.g., SiO2, TiO2, Al2O3, Sb2O3) have been reported [5]. The rich surface chemistry, high surface area and possibly porous morphology of these fillers allow them to absorb electrolytic compounds or solvents, effectively retaining these substances within the polymer network. Moreover, the interaction between the surface groups on fillers and the ionic substance in the electrolyte may promote ion dissociation, while the interaction between fillers and the polymer networks provides additional conductive interface areas, both are conducive to increase ionic conductivity of GPEs. Additionally, some fillers can be used as crosslinking agents for polymer matrices, inhibiting their recombination and improving mechanical strength of the structure. For example, as frequently used inorganic fillers, TiO2 nanoparticles exhibit acid-base characteristic and vacant oxygen coordination sites on their surface, which could contribute to diminishing of the inherent crystalline structure within polymers and increase the ionic conductivity of GPEs [129–131]. They could also serve as the photoinitiator for in-situ photopolymerization processes and as nano-reinforcements within GPEs, providing inorganic crosslinking and leveraging the introduction of supramolecular effects to improve the mechanical strength of the electrolytes [61,62]. Inorganic SiO2 nanoparticles have been commonly used as fillers in GPEs, where they act as crosslinkers, plasticizers and solvent (e.g., water) retention agents [72,73,76]. Their addition could lead to reduced crystallinity of polymers and increased amorphous region of GPEs, thereby improving ionic conductivity [132].
