Moreover, the hydroxyl groups present on the SiO2 surface can create hydrogen bonds with solvent molecules, while the silanol groups of SiO2 can condense with the hydroxyl groups of polymers to form a cross-linked network structure, allowing the stable work of GPEs at high temperature. A GPE was prepared by mixing PVA solution with silicetungstic acid (SiWA) and H3PO4 [133], where SiO2 nanoparticles with diameters of 10–20 nm were introduced as inorganic fillers. SiO2 nanoparticles showed cross-linking effect on the PVA polymer. Their water retention effect was achieved through formation of chemical bonds between SiO2 and other components, including SiOC bridges formed between PVA and nano-SiO2, and additional hydrogen bonds formed between SiWA, PVA and nano-SiO2. Another GPE was prepared by the mixture of SiO2 dispersed hydroxyl silicone oil with PVA and LiCl dissolved EG [134]. By combining the GPE with AC/CC electrodes, the corresponding FSC could withstand high temperatures of up to 80 °C with a cell voltage of 1.7 V. It also showed the ability to endure various dynamic excitations like bending (no capacitance degradation under bending state from 0° to 180°), compression (a capacitance retention of 90% after compression of the FSC to 50% for 200 times), and impact (a capacitance retention of 88% by dissipating the impact force from 570 to 81 N). The addition of SiO2 in an ionogel consisted of polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) and 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bis(fluorosulfonyl)imide (EMIM·FSI) led to increased ionic conductivity of the ionogel, and thus increases of ca. 72% and 64% in the capacitances of related quasi-solid-state SCs at 10 mV s−1 at 25 and 100 °C, respectively [73]. MMT containing mixed metal oxides has been used as a thermal stabilization additive in GPEs of HT-FSCs [59,101,105,106,135,136]. The layered structure of MMT also provides conductive channels for various active ions to move freely in GPEs, resulting in improved ionic conductivity of the electrolyte. An organohydrogel was synthesized using PVA as the polymer matric, H2SO4 as the ion supplier, DMSO/water binary system as the solvent, and MMT as the filler [106]. The strong hydrogen bond interaction between oxygen-containing groups on MMT sheets and hydroxyl groups on the PVA polymer allowed stable operation of the formed FSC based on graphene electrodes at 90 °C. Meanwhile, the strong hydrogen bonds between water and DMSO molecules significantly weakened the solvent effect between ions and water molecules, promoting ionic migration kinetics (Fig. 10 a). As the temperature increased from −50 to 90 °C, the capacitance of the FSC first increased and then decreased (Fig. 10b, c), owing to the segmental relaxation of PVA polymers near the glass-transition temperature. Additionally, the plasticization effect of MMT sheets in the PVA framework improved the uniformity of the GPE, and allowed it to maintain its original morphology even after twisting, bending and stretching (Fig. 10d). A reduction of 9% in initial specific capacitance was found after 1 000 bends (Fig. 10e), ensuring a high mechanical stability. In ionogels composed of PEO, bentonite clay, and an IL of EMIM·BF4, BMIM·BF4 or 1-hexyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate (HMIM·BF4), the addition of bentonite clay (i.e. layer-structured MMT) not only increased the thermal stability of ionogels by generating hydrogen-bond interactions between hydroxy groups in PEO polymers and oxygen-containing groups in clay, but also inhibited the self-discharging of related quasi-solid-state SCs at high temperature of 70 °C due to the adsorption of cations on the negatively charged surface of clay [59]. With increased chain length of HMIM+>BMIM+>EMIM+, the adsorption capacity of cations on bentonite clay also increased (Fig. 10 f), leading to decreased self-discharging of corresponding SCs at 70 °C. The FSCs assembled with AC electrodes and HMIM·BF4 based ionogel demonstrated a lower self-discharging rate of 54.6% voltage drops after 10 h at 70 °C, compared to that (63.7% at 70 °C for 10 h) measured on conventional liquid SC (Fig. 10g). HNTs as another type of clay has been selected as anisotropic nanofillers for GPEs due to their versatile advantages of nanotubular structure, high specific surface area, high mechanical strength, abundant hydroxyl groups, environmental friendliness and low cost [77,137]. The addition of HNTs in in-situ cross-linked cellulose/EMIM·OAc system led to improved mechanical performance and thermal stability of the ionogel [77]. This was because HNTs possessed abundant Al–OH groups that interacted strongly with hydroxyl groups on cellulose chains via hydrogen bonding. With the presence of HNTs, the ionic conductivity of the ionogel also increased significantly, due to the generation of ionic channels for ion transport. Further increase of the ionic conductivity was achieved by increasing HNT content, and shear induced orientation of HNTs that provided aligned and continuous transport channels (Fig. 10h, i). The related FSC with sandwiched structure using AC electrodes showed good cycling stability as the operating temperature increased from 25 to 120 °C (5.7% and 7.5% decay of the initial capacitance after 5 000 charging/discharging cycles at 1 A g−1, respectively). In addition to the above oxides, other high temperature resistant materials can also be good thermal stability additives for GPEs, such as methacrylate graphene oxide (MGO). MGO with unsaturated double bonds was first synthesized via a substitution reaction between the oxygen functional groups (hydroxyl and epoxy groups) of graphene oxide and 3-(trimethoxysilyl)propyl methacrylate, and then used as cross-linking points to polymerize with AAm monomers with the presence of N, N, N’, N’-tetramethyl-ethylenediamine as the catalyst and APS as the initiator [97]. A GPE was then produced by immersing MGO cross-linked PAAm in a glycol/water solution containing sulfuric acid (Fig. 11 a, b). Due to the presence of abundant hydrogen bonds interconnecting the cross-linked polymer chains, in case of partial hydrogen bond destruction under external stress, new hydrogen bonds could form immediately to reconnect the polymer chains and disperse energy uniformly throughout the polymer network [98]. As a result, the MGO/PAAm GPE exhibited excellent mechanical properties, which maintained excellent reversible elasticity and dimensional stability even at high temperature of 100 °C. The FSC with the integration of this polyelectrolyte and CNT/worm-like-structured PANI nanofibers-based electrodes exhibited a capacitance of 96.2 mF cm−2 at the current density of 0.223 mA cm−2, an energy density of 8.55 μWh cm−2 at a power density of 85.3 μW cm−2 and a capacitance retention of 75.3% after 3 000 cycles at 4.46 mA cm−2 under 100 °C (Fig. 11c, d). The reduction of capacitance observed during the lifetime test was due to the evaporation of EG and H2O upon a certain degree during prolonged cycling at the high temperature, eventually leading to dropped ionic conductivity of the electrolyte. MXene, such as Ti3C2Tx, has been used as a thermally stable filler in GPEs [80,99,138]. The abundant surface functional groups on MXene offer cross-linking sites to combine MXene with gel systems or polymers. For example, in a poly(AA-co-N-hydroxyethyl acrylamide)/LiCl/EG organic gel doped with Ti3C2Tx, hydrogen bond interactions were generated between the surface functional groups on MXene and the carboxyl/hydroxyl groups in AA and N-hydroxyethyl acrylamide monomers [138]. The introduction of a proper amount of MXene led to increased mechanical properties of the gel including breaking strength and elongation at break. By assembling the GPE with AC electrodes, the formed FSC showed good long-term cycling performance even at a high temperature of 80 °C (96.8% capacitance retention after 10 000 charging/discharging cycles). In a PVA based organohydrogel electrolyte formed by soaking a PVA based hydrogel in 3 M H2SO4 EG/H2O, Ti3C2Tx nanosheets were incorporated to improve its ionic conductivity and generate extra three-dimensional porous network structure in the gel, which were beneficial for ion transmission [99]. After adding Ti3C2Tx in the organohydrogel, the related FSCs based on large Ti3C2Tx nanosheets/aramid nanofibers electrodes showed an increased capacitance from 67 to 83 F g−1 at 0.5 A g−1, a reduced equivalent series resistance from 12.4 to 9.1 Ω. The FSC could also work effectively at a temperature of up to 60 °C with a further enhanced capacitance to 106 F g−1. It should be noted that MXene is relatively sensitive to water and oxygen at elevated temperatures, which should be considered when applying it to HT-FSCs. Several strategies can be employed to improve its thermal stability, such as surface modification, encapsulation within a protective layer, and a controlled environment. It is recommended to examine the structure and composition of MXene after the high-temperature operation of related FSCs over a specific duration to confirm its thermal and electrochemical stability. 4 Electrode materials for HT-FSCs To ensure effective performance and stability of FSCs under elevated temperatures, electrode materials need to meet specific requirements of good thermal stability at intended operating temperatures, good chemical and electrochemical stability, high electrical conductivity, good chemical compatibility with the selected GPE, large specific surface area, flexibility, low cost and ease of preparation. These requirements actually arise due to the challenges posed by high temperatures and the desire for high energy storage capabilities. In Table 1, Table 2 , Table 3 and Table 4, the electrode materials used for some HT-FSCs are summarized. They could be divided into carbon materials, pseudocapacitive metal derived compounds and conducting polymers. Carbon materials possess the feature of high thermal, chemical and electrochemical stability, high conductivity, high specific surface area and good mechanical strength, whereas most pseudocapacitive materials show relatively low conductivity and low mechanical properties. However, the capacitance of common carbon materials mainly stems from the capacitive ion accumulation at the electrode/electrolyte interfaces, much smaller than that of pseudocapacitive materials originated from their redox reactions. Therefore, pseudocapacitive materials are often combined with carbon materials to construct composite materials with integrated advantages of individual materials [139,140]. Besides electrode active materials, a conventional electrode also contains binders, conducting additives and a current collector. The most commonly used conductive agent is carbon black, which encounters no potential issues when applied in high-temperature environments [141]. Conversely, polymer binders like polyvynilidene fluoride, polytetrafluoroethylene and Nafion exhibit relatively low melting points (e.g., 155–196 °C for polyvynilidene fluoride, depending on the preparation and testing processes) [142,143]. It is known that binders are used to combine electrode materials and conductive additives together on a current collector. Although binders are usually inactive and constitute a low content of 5 to 10 wt% of the total electrode mass, they affect the thermal behavior, usable temperature range and electrochemical performance of the electrode. A current collector functions as a mechanical support for the electrode and is employed to collect electric current. It should possess the features of high conductivity, robust and stable bonding with electrode materials, small contact resistance to electrode materials, and high chemical stability to the electrolyte, etc. Metal foils and carbon materials (e.g., CC) have been mostly used as current collectors in HT-FSCs, due to their good thermal stability, high thermal conductivity and high flexibility. Nevertheless, for some metal current collectors, an insulating oxide coating tends to form at elevated temperatures, resulting in enhanced contact resistance. 4.1 Carbon materials The high stability of carbon materials under harsh conditions and environments makes them suitable candidates for high-temperature applications. According to TGA, an AC prepared from rice husk using an activation temperature of 800 °C showed a minor weight loss of 3.6 wt% when subjected to heating in the range of 80 to 350 °C [144]. A CNT/r-GO hybrid carbon material displayed a low weight loss of 4.3 wt% upon heating to 400 °C, due to the oxidation of amorphous carbon [145]. Negligible mass loss (ca. 0.2 wt%) was observed on boron-doped diamond by heating it to 800 °C in air atmosphere [146]. Besides, carbon materials show the advantages of versatility in forms and dimensions, porous structure and tunable porosity, accessible and short pathways for ion transfer, tunable wettability to different electrolytes, low weight and cost, etc. Their thermal conductivity can vary from the level of thermal insulation, to the order of 103 W m−1·K−1. For instance, depending on factors such as structures, forms (e.g., films, buckypapers and bundled systems) and synthesis methods, CNTs exhibited a diverse range of thermal conductivity, spanning from 0.1 to 6600 W m−1·K−1 [147]. Hence, carbon materials (e.g., AC, graphene, CNTs) are the most commonly used electrode materials for HT-FSCs [89,148,149]. AC electrodes can withstand operating temperatures of as high as 200 °C [61,65]. They are usually produced through carbonization of natural or synthetic carbon-rich precursors, followed by physical activation at high temperatures in the presence of gases (e.g., CO2, steam) and/or chemical activations involving chemical activating agents (e.g., KOH, H3PO4, ZnCl2) [150]. ACs are highly porous with high specific surface areas and a broad range of pore sizes. The specific surface area, pore size distribution, and surface functionalities of ACs are highly dependent on the used precursors and activation processes. For example, AC prepared from Coconut shell via a steam activation method showed porous structure, a BET specific surface area of 1260 m2 g−1 and a pore volume of 1.8 cm3 g−1 [135]. By using it as the cathode, Zn/CC as the anode and PVA/Zn(ClO4)2/MMT hydrogel as the electrolyte, a Zi-ion FSC was fabricated. It possessed a large working temperature range from −50 to 80 °C, with high energy storage capacities and good cycling stability. It could deliver high energy densities of 190.3 W h kg−1 at 89.8 W kg−1 at 25 °C and 138.6 W h kg−1 at 18 kW kg−1 at 60 °C. Meanwhile, the capacitance retention after 5500 charging/discharging cycles at 5 A g−1 under 60 °C was measured to be 80%, mainly resulting from water evaporation in the hydrogel. Many studies are dedicated to enhancing the performance of carbon based electrodes. Possible strategies are the design and development of advanced carbon materials, achieved through tailoring their morphology and microstructure to possess a large surface area accessible by ions and a controlled pore size distribution, and/or by doping them with heteroatoms. These processes may also lead to changes in the thermal characteristics of the electrodes. Investigating their thermal performance and assessing their suitability for HT-FSCs is crucial for the development of high-performance HT-FSCs. For example, the graphitization degree of electrospun carbon nanofibers was found to influence the temperature-dependence behavior of their potassium ion storage capability, a factor that should be considered during the design of potassium-ion FSCs [151]. Additionally, a high porosity might not be conducive to efficient heat conduction [152]. It was reported that the thermal conductivity of a dense graphene foam (λGF) with different porosities (f) was correlated to that of solid graphene (λG) as λ GF = λ G ( 1 - f ) 3 / 2 , where the pores was assumed as randomly sized spheres [153]. A hierarchically porous carbon was synthesized with a microzone-combustion strategy using k-carrageenan as the precursor, sodium citrate and sodium nitrate mixture as the combustion agents (Fig. 12 a, b) [36]. Compared to the carbon materials produced without the addition of sodium citrate and sodium nitrate, and with the addition of only sodium citrate or sodium nitrate, it possessed a higher specific surface area (2 253.6 m2 g−1), a richer porosity with hierarchical pores in the size ranges of 2–4 nm and 10–60 nm, a mixed microstructure of sp2 ordered area and sp3 defective area, and thus higher electrochemical performance in aqueous KOH (6.0 M) and WIS (7.0 M LiTFSI) solutions. By matching the porous carbon electrodes with a WIS-GPE composed of LiTFSI and PAA/PAAm, the formed quasi-solid-state SC showed a wide cell voltage of 2.5 V, a specific capacitance of 191.1 F g−1 at the current density of 0.5 A g−1, an energy density of 41.3 W h kg−1 at a power density of 12 100 W kg−1, capacitance retentions of 90.1% and 90.2% after 10 000 charging/discharging cycles at 10 A/g and after 200 bending cycles at 90° bending angle, respectively. By increasing the working temperature from 0 to 60 °C, the capacitance of the device increased due to improved ionic conductivity and interface kinetics, which recovered to the initial value at 0 °C after high temperature measurements (Fig. 12c). The doping of heteroatoms (e.g., nitrogen, sulfur, oxygen, boron, and phosphorus) introduces new functional groups on the electrode surface, enhancing surface electrochemical activity and potentially inducing pseudocapacitive behavior. It brings defects and vacancies, providing more active site for ion adsorption. In addition, the insertion of heteroatoms into the carbon lattice structure can lead to an improved charge density and the activation of carbon electrons around these heteroatoms [154]. In particular, the doped N atoms exhibit unpaired electrons in the outermost orbit that are beneficial for promoting charge transport and increasing electrical conductivity of the electrode materials. The newly generated surface functional groups include pyridinic-nitrogen, pyrrolic-nitrogen, quaternary-nitrogen, and pyridine-nitrogen-oxide. They show the abilities to conjugate with π-conjugated rings, improve charge mobility as an electron-donor, improve the conductance, and accelerate electron transfer with the production of a positive charge on carbon, respectively. The introduction of electron-rich element S provides extra polarized surface and pseudosites, and expands the interlayer distance in carbon. On the other hand, the changes in structural and chemical properties of carbon materials induced by the introduction of these impurities also bring about varied thermal characteristics of the materials. For instance, the thermal stability of nitrogen and/or sulfur doped carbon nano-onions were found to be lower than that of pristine carbon nano-onion, as indicated by TGA. In contrast to pristine carbon nano-onion, which exhibited almost no weight loss by heating above 500 °C, weight losses were observed at lower temperatures in doped carbon nano-onions due to the decomposition of oxygen-containing functional groups (e.g., CO, COOH and COC) at 250–350 °C, other functional groups like NH and OH at 270–370 °C, pyrrole rings at 240–400 °C, pyridine rings at 300–500 °C, and thiophene rings at 300–600 °C [155]. After doping MWCNT films with nitrogen, the thermal conductivities were dropped from ∼74 W m−1 K−1 to the values of ∼16–27 W m−1 K−1, mainly attributed to greater extent of defects in N-doped MWCNTs compared to those in un-doped MWCNTs [156]. Moreover, the careful selection of appropriate dopants is crucial to avoid negative effects, such as undesirable side reactions and the decomposition of organic electrolytes, which could result in decreased stability, reduced charge storage capacity, and capacitance decay over time [154]. Heteroatoms doped carbon materials have been applied as electrode materials for the construction of HT-FSCs. After N-doping of rGO fiber-based electrode materials with doping contents ranging from 2.0 to 2.9 at%, the capacitance of the related FSCs using 8.96 M LiCl based WIS-GPE increased by 2.4–5.3 times. The reasons for such an increase were as follows: i) increased active sites, facilitated reaction kinetics and promoted ion adsorption/desorption ability through N-doping; ii) additional pseudocapacitance generated by N/O-containing functional groups (Eqs. (11)–(13)) [44]. The FSC was capable of operating at a high temperature of 70 °C. N, S, and O atoms co-doped carbon was synthesized simply through the polymerization of benzoquinone/sulfourea followed by a carbonization/activation process. The co-existence of micro- and meso-pores offered high surface area of up to 2917 m2 g−1 and multi pathways accessible for ion transfer. The presence of ternary-dopants improved the electrical conductance, electrochemical activity and wettability of the carbon material. By using the ternary-doped carbon as electrodes and 7 m LiTFSI based WIS in gel support as the electrolyte, the formed FSC with a cell voltage of 2.3 V delivered a maximum energy density of 34.3 W h kg−1, 91.6% of which still remained in a 180° bending state [42]. The FSC was demonstrated to perform effectively under high-temperature conditions of 80 °C. (11) CO + Li+ + e– ↔ COLi (12) CO– ↔ CO + e– (13) Pyridinic N + Li+ + e– ↔ Pyridinic N−Li Hybrid carbon materials, which integrate various carbon-based constituents, have been widely investigated. These studies leverage the unique properties of each component to create materials that exhibit substantially enhanced performance. A free-standing hybrid material of rGO/CNT was produced by interleaving CNTs among rGO platelets with mesoporous structure [11]. CNTs acted as bridges between isolated rGO, providing conducting pathways to enhance the conductivity and promoting rGO distribution to improve the mechanical strength of the film. Mesoporous configurations offered the capacity to create extra space to mitigate the strain arising from the volume changes under heating and under cooling. The FSC constructed by assembling rGO/CNT electrodes with EMIM·TFSI ionogel electrolyte presented excellent electrochemical performance and high durability even at extreme temperatures of up to 200 °C and down to −40 °C. The capacitance remained almost unchanged after 72 h operation and after 500 bends at 200 °C. Similarly, in a graphene/carbon black nanoparticle hybrid material, carbon black nanoparticles behaved as conductive pillars intercalated into the graphene nanosheets to connect the neighboring layers and prevent restacking/aggregation of graphene nanosheets [157]. Hence, compared to graphene, the hybrid material possessed higher conductivity, faster diffusion of electrolyte ions, and a larger specific area. When combined with a cross-linked PVA/H2SO4 porous GPE, the FSC based on the hybrid electrodes also showed an increased specific capacitance (from 107.5 F g−1 to 144.5 F g−1 at 0.5 A g−1) and a better rate capability compared to the FSC based on graphene electrodes. Moreover, it could operate well under bent conditions and at high temperatures of up to 80 °C. A capacitance retention of 78.3% was achieved at 70 °C after 1000 charging/discharging cycles. 4.2 Metal derived compounds Metal derived compounds, such as metal oxides, metal chalcogenides and MXene have been used as electrode materials for HT-FSCs. The additional pseudocapacitance raised from Faradaic redox reactions of these materials leads to enhanced electrochemical performance of FSCs. Metal oxide, like MnO2, NiO, Co3O4 showed good thermal stability [158–161]. Nanoscale MnO2 with different porosity and surface area undergone weight losses of ∼2.7%–12.7% during heating from room temperature to around 225 °C in an air flow. Further weight reductions of ∼1.9%–3.7% were observed upon continued heating to ca. 500 °C. The former was attributed to the evaporation of surface adsorbed water and uncoordinated interlayer water, while the latter was due to the removal of water from the hydration shell of interlayer cations [158]. A metal oxide of Ni-doped MnO2 was chemically deposited on a carbon substrate that was prepared by densely growth of N-doped CNTs on the walls of N-doped 3D porous graphene ( Fig. 13 a–d) [162]. The composite material combined the advantages of individual components (e.g., fast ion/electron transport and high conductivity of carbon materials, high theoretical specific capacitance of MnO2). The electronegative Ni dopants in MnO2 enhanced the oxygen evolution potential due to facilitated charge transfer at the oxygen sites, and thus enlarged the potential window of the electrode material. It was used as the positive electrode, and paired with a N-doped 3D porous graphene/N-doped CNTs negative electrode for the construction of an asymmetric FSC, where LiClO4/PVA hydrogel was applied as the GPE. The FSC exhibited a large cell voltage of 2.4 V, a high volumetric energy density of 78.88 mWh cm−3, excellent flexibility with highly coincident CV curves at bending states of 0°–180°, and good electrochemical stability over a wide temperature range of −20–70 °C (Fig. 13e, f). Another asymmetric FSC was fabricated using MnO2/NiCo2O4 deposited on CC as the positive electrode, and N-doped carbon nanofiber as the negative electrode [100]. An organohydrogel was prepared as the GPE, containing KOH, a mixed solvent of H2O/EG with a volume ratio of 1/1, and dual polymer networks of PVA and in-situ polymerized Poly(AAm-co-AMPS). MnO2/NiCo2O4 nanostructures with a core–shell mesoporous structure possessed multiple ion diffusion channels beneficial for accelerating ion transfer kinetics. The FSC could be operated over a high voltage window of 0–1.7 V and a wide temperature range from −20 to 80 °C. By increasing the operating temperature from 25 to 80 °C, the maximal capacitance of the FSC was increased from 127.2 to 300.0 F g−1, and its maximal energy density was enhanced from 51.1 to 122.0 Wh kg−1 at a power density of 850 W kg−1. After 5 000 repetitive charging/discharging cycles at 80 °C under unchanged form and under bending at a bending radius of 7 mm, the FSC showed capacitance retentions of 71.3% and 80%, respectively, which were ca. 80% and 88% at 25 °C under the same testing conditions. This indicated good electrochemical, thermal and mechanical stability of the FSC. The lower long-term stability at 80 °C was ascribed to the drying of the organohydrogen induced by solvent evaporation. Metal sulfides have been widely adopted as electrode materials in electrochemical energy storage systems due to their high specific capacity, good electrical conductivity, low electronegativity, and high redox activity [163–165]. Certain metal sulfides have been utilized in the fabrication of SCs capable of withstanding elevated temperatures, including CuSbS2 (15–55 °C) [166], Co1-xS (10–70 °C) [167] and Co9S8 (10–70 °C) [168]. It should be noted that metal sulfides may experience desulfurization, oxidation, and decomposition when subjected to high temperatures in air atmosphere. For example, according to TGA of Co9S8/N-doped carbon layer in air within a temperature range of 25–600 °C, coupled with ex-situ XRD measurements of the residues from TGA experiments at 250, 350, and 550 °C, the initial weight loss observed below 200 °C was assignable to the evaporation of water [169]. Subsequent weight loss, initiating around 250 °C, was ascribed to the progressive oxidation of the Co9S8 phase to Co3O4, followed by the formation of the CoSO4 phase, and the combustion of the carbon content. The thermal stability of metal sulfides is known to be dependent on their composition, valence states, structures, crystallinity, and morphologies. In the assembly of HT-FSCs, metal sulfide Co9S8-NiCo2S4 core–shell nanoneedle films were deposited on CC [170]. The hollow Co9S8 nanoneedles acted as frameworks, offering numerous active sites for the formation of NiCo2S4. The dendritic NiCo2S4 nanosheets interconnected the nanoneedles, significantly enhancing the material’s surface area and ion diffusion pathways, which in turn accelerated the charge transfer rate and the kinetics of electrochemical reactions. An asymmetric FSC was constructed using Co9S8-NiCo2S4/CC as the positive electrode, AC/CC as the negative electrode, and PVA-KOH hydrogel as the electrolyte, which delivered a wide voltage window of 0–1.6 V, a maximum energy density of 56.44 W h kg−1 at 795 W kg−1 and a maximum power density of 8153 W kg−1 at 29.44 W h kg−1. Under conditions of bending and twisting up to 90°, as well as after 100 cycles of bending or twisting at 90°, no significant deformation was observed in the CVs recorded at 100 mV s−1 when compared to the original. As the operating temperature was increased from RT to 80 °C, the CVs showed almost no change up to 60 °C, with a slight decline noted at 80 °C. MXenes refer to a class of 2D materials composed of transition metal carbides/nitrides. They exhibit intrinsically conductive nature, high surface area, rich and tunable surface chemistry, making them attractive in energy storage applications [105,171,172]. MXenes like Mo2TiC2, Ti3C2Tx, vanadium carbide (V4C3) were found to be thermally stable in inert gas atmosphere (e.g., N2 and Ar) at temperatures of even up to ca. 800 °C [173–175]. For instance, only a minor weight loss of 1 wt% was observed on Mo2TiC2 in a temperature range from room temperature to 1000 °C in a N2 flow, attributed to the evaporation of adsorbed water molecules and the removal of attached surface functional groups [173]. However, MXenes tend to oxidate at high temperatures in an oxygen atmosphere [176,177]. For example, for a Ti3C2 MXene, a notable weight gain of 19.63 wt% from 200 to 368 °C was observed in its TGA curve obtained in an oxygen atmosphere. Correspondingly, a pronounced and exothermic peak at 285 °C was identified in the DSC curve. Nevertheless, the small weight loss of 0.54 wt% observed from room temperature to 200 °C also indicates its suitability for use as electrode materials in HT-FSCs [176]. Fiber shaped Ti3C2Tx electrodes were synthesized by assembly of Ti3C2Tx nanosheets [178]. They showed a high aspect ratio, a sheet-to-sheet lamellar structure that facilitated the intercalation and adsorption of ions (e.g., Na+) on Ti3C2Tx nanosheets for charge storage, and thus high volumetric capacitance. The symmetric FSC based on Ti3C2Tx fiber electrodes and a GPE composed of an EG-water mixed solvent with PVA/NaClO4 could deliver a specific capacitance of 41 F cm−3 and a volumetric energy density of 5 mW h cm−3 at 28.3 mW cm−3. The FSC also demonstrated reliable performance across a temperature range of −40 °C to 40 °C and a bending angle span of 0° to 180°. However, the restacking of Ti3C2Tx nanosheets can lead to a reduction in the electrode’s electrochemical performance. Therefore, 1D organic aramid nanofibers were introduced into the interlayer spacer of inorganic Ti3C2Tx nanosheets [99]. With the inhibition of nanosheets restacking and expansion of interlayer spacing, the Ti3C2Tx/aramid composite electrode showed higher rate performance, improved flexibility and tensile strength, as compared to the original Ti3C2Tx electrode. 4.3 Conducting polymers Conductive polymer materials, including PEDOT, PANI and PPy, have gained widespread utilization in flexible devices owing to their intrinsic polymerizable characteristics. This feature allows them to be compatible with diverse flexible substrates, while their extended π–electron conjugations ensure high conductivity of these materials. As pseudocapacitive electrode materials, they provided high specific capacitance via Faraday oxidation–reduction processes. Compared to carbon materials and metal oxides, conducting polymers possess relatively lower thermal stability. During the TGA of PANI in air, it displayed a three-stage weight loss behavior. This included the loss of surface absorbed water from room temperature to 150 °C, the elimination of dopant molecules from 150 to 280 °C, and the decomposition of polymer chain from 350 to 600 °C [179]. Similar weight loss phenomenon was observed on PPy [180,181]. The synthesis of composite materials by combining conducting polymers with carbon materials (e.g., CNTs) could improve the thermal stability of these polymers [182,183]. PANI was prepared by chemical oxidative polymerization of aniline and subsequently coated on graphite paper [80]. The polymerization time influenced the micromorphology and thus the electrochemical performance of PANI. Spherical PANI with the highest capacitance and lowest impedance was obtained with a proper reaction time. The acid-doping of PANI using methanesulfonic acid (MSA) further increased its conductivity through the formation of polar delocalization by combining hydrogen ions with N atoms in the imine groups. An FSC was constructed, composed of the PANI/graphite paper electrodes and an ionogel electrolyte consisting of VMIM·TFSI, EMIM·TFSI, MSA, PAAm, and MXene. The device showed pseudocapacitive behavior with the appearance of redox peaks in CVs and corresponding plateaus in GCD curves at various temperatures in the range of −20–90 °C. As the temperature reached 90 °C, a specific capacitance of 204.6 F g−1 and an energy density of 40.9 W h kg−1 were achieved. In another work, PANI was loaded on CC via an in-situ chemical oxidative polymerization route to improve the electrochemical performance of CC [70]. Core–shell structures were formed by abundant PANI fragments wrapped on the outer layer of carbon fibers, leading to enhanced specific surface area and redox sites that were beneficial for ion migration. A related quasi-solid-state SC was formed by integrating the PANI/CC electrodes with a double-network polyzwitterionic GPE composed of EMIM·BF4 and PVA/poly(AAm-co-VBIPS). The increase of working temperatures from −60 to 50 °C promoted the redox effect of PANI, leading to a high specific capacitance of 254 mF cm−2 at 50 °C. The device demonstrated a good cycle performance, showing capacitance retentions of 91 % and 85.6 % after 5 000 charging/discharging cycles at 2 mA cm−2 at 25 and 50 °C, respectively. PANI could also be synthesized using electrochemical oxidative polymerization of aniline monomers. For example, PANI was electrodeposited on a MWCNT film to integrated the pseudocapacitive nature of PANI and the high conductivity of MWCNTs [98]. When combined with an organohydrogel electrolyte (EG-H2O/H2SO4/PAAm/MGO), the formed FSC presented high flexibility with marginal changes in electrochemical performance under compression or bending. It could properly operate over a wide temperature range of −30–100 °C. At the high temperature of 100 °C, the device showed a capacitance of 157.2 F·g−1 at 0.5 A·g−1, and a capacitance retention of 76.5 % after 4 000 charging/discharging cycles at 2 A·g−1. By coating PPy on carboxylated CNTs (CNT-COOH), the additional pseudocapacitance caused by the redox reactions of PPy led to significantly increased capacitance of related SCs [96]. However, the relatively low conductivity of PPy led to reduced charge transport from the PPy shell to the CNT-COOH core at high loading amounts, resulting in increased internal resistance and thus reduced capacitance. As the temperature elevated from 25 to 80 °C, the FSC based on the optimal PPy@CNT-COOH and an organohydrogel containing LiCl and EG/H2O binary solvent demonstrated a gradual decrease in charge transfer resistance and an increase in CV loop area, mainly due to the accelerated ion migration rate. However, the charging time increased and the discharging time decreased during GCD tests at 0.2 A g−1, probably ascribed to water evaporation and the deterioration of interface adhesion, leading to a capacitance retention of 75.2%. Nevertheless, the SC showed good cycling stability at high temperatures. After 1 000 cycles at 60 °C, 98.4% of the initial capacitance remained, which was 70.91% after operating at 80 °C for 6 h. PPy/CNTs composite electrodes could also be obtained by coupling CNT ink with a PPy film prepared using an electrochemical deposition method [95]. The presence of CNTs on the PPy film led to the formation of 3D networked structure (Fig. 14 a), resulting in facilitated ion/electron transfer and thus enhanced capacitance. However, the cycling stability of PPy/CNTs electrode was lower than that of PPy electrode due to CNT shedding over extended cycles. An FSC was fabricated using PPy/CNTs as the electrodes and a double-network polymer organohydrogel (LiCl/EG/H2O/PAMPS/PAAm) as the electrolyte. The FSC showed outstanding flexibility with well-maintained specific capacitance under deformations of bending and stretching (Fig. 14b, c). The good water retention ability of the FSC allowed it to work well at different temperatures ranging from 30 to 80 °C (Fig. 14d–f). Another PPy electrode was formed directly on a EG/H2O/PAAm/EMIM·BF4/MMT organohydrogel electrolyte by in-situ polymerization in a solution containing pyrrole and a piece of the organohydrogel [101]. The integrated FSC with good compatibility between electrodes and the electrolyte showed high ionic conductivity (33.3 mS cm−1 at 40 °C), low charge transfer resistance and rapid ion diffusivity. It possessed high mechanical robust under stretching, twisting, and bending, with capacitance retentions of 67% after 500 cycles of 100% stretching-releasing, 92.5% after 500 twisting-releasing cycles, and 97.3% by bending from 0° to 180°, respectively. Additionally, it had a temperature tolerance within a range of −30–60 °C. 5 Conclusions and outlook Recent advances of GPEs and electrode materials used in HT-FSCs have been comprehensively reviewed. Strategies for enhancing the thermal stability of GPEs have been discussed, including the formation of WIS-GPEs and IL-GPEs, the use of mixed solvents, the engineering of polymer hosts, and the addition of fillers. WIS based hydrogels contain a high concentration of salts, whose volume or weight is higher than that of the water solvent. The salt ions are capable of anchoring nearly all water molecules in solvent-sheath structures, significantly suppressing water activity. This enables the formation of HT-FSCs with an expanded electrochemical stability window of up to 2.5 V and an operation temperature higher than 100 °C. Due to the inherent properties of ILs, including high electrochemical stability, high thermal stability and non-volatility, the employment of ionogels in FSCs has achieved a cell voltage of up to 4.0 V and an operation temperature of up to 200 °C. However, simultaneously increasing the ionic conductivity and mechanical performance of ionogels remains a challenge, which can be addressed through several potential methods, such as the incorporation of solid/liquid solvents or inorganic fillers, structural/morphological engineering of ionogels, the integration of ILs in in-situ polymerization processes, and the combination of ionogels with flexible and robust scaffolds. Mixed solvents merge the properties of their individual constituents and acquire additional characteristics through their combination. In thermally stable organohydrogels, organic solvents with high boiling points, such as GLY, EG, and DMSO, are commonly used to mix with water. These organic solvents can form hydrogen bond interactions with water, leading to reduced amounts of free water in GPEs and increased ability of GPEs to withstand high temperatures. DESs formed by combining hydrogen bond donors with hydrogen bond acceptors exhibit characteristics similar to ILs, notably low vapor pressure. This feature makes eutectogels, synthesized from DESs, promising candidates for thermally stable GPEs in HT-FSCs. Moreover, as a crucial element within GPEs, the composition, structure and properties of polymer hosts determine the flexibility, ion transport capability, and overall stability of the electrolyte system. Various strategies, such as in-situ polymerization/co-polymerization, double-network formation and cross-linking, can be employed to modify the properties of polymer frameworks and the interactions between macromolecules and solvents/salts, aiming to meet the demanding requirements for exceptional electrochemical and mechanical performance in high-temperature environments. Additionally, various heat-resistant fillers (e.g., carbon materials, ceramic particles and clays) often exhibit high surface area and rich surface functional groups. By incorporating these fillers into GPEs, effective interactions and/or bonds can be formed between the fillers and other components (e.g., solvents and polymer frameworks). This is beneficial for stabilizing the structure of GPEs and maintaining their integrity at elevated temperatures, ensuring consistent electrochemical performance over time. As for flexible electrode materials, carbon materials, metal derived compounds, conducting polymers and their composite materials have been applied. They should possess excellent compatibility to GPEs and are capable of maximizing the performance of GPEs. Among them, carbon materials with high conductivity, high surface area and high thermal stability have been most commonly applied. The thermal properties of carbon materials can be altered through the engineering of microstructure (e.g., porosity and pore size distribution), the doping of heteroatoms and the presence of impurities. For metal derived compounds and conducting polymers, although they could deliver high specific capacitance via redox reactions, their physicochemical properties might be changed at high temperature due to oxidation or decomposition reactions. The selection and development of GPEs and electrode materials for HT-FSCs should correspond to the intended temperature range, ensuring both high electrochemical and mechanical performance of the cells while meeting specific application needs. To further improve the thermal, electrochemical and mechanical performance of HT-FSCs and broaden their application ranges, it is necessary to design and develop novel GPEs and electrode materials, implement smart assembly schemes for HT-FSCs, gain a comprehensive understanding of their fundamentals and explore their practical applications: (1) GPEs. GPEs play a key role in maintaining the reliability and performance of HT-FSCs. Despite the application of various strategies to synthesize GPEs with high thermal stability, volume shrinkage in GPEs at elevated temperatures remains an issue due to solvent evaporation and polymer network contraction. This shrinkage can give rise to several problems, including: i) decreased contact area between the electrode and electrolyte and thus reduced ion transport efficiency; ii) delamination of electrode layers and failure of the FSC; iii) poor heat dissipation and non-uniform temperature distribution within the device due to the generation of possible voids or hot spots in GPEs; iv) reduced mechanical integrity and durability. Further development of novel GPEs is required through optimization of the formulation and processing conditions, strengthening network structures of heat-resistant polymers via physical/chemical crosslinking methods or optimized polymerization processes (e.g., variation of monomer ratio), and reasonable structural design (e.g., multi-layer structures), etc. Lowering the price of GPEs is important to expand their application scope and improve their market competitiveness. For example, ionogels suffer from high raw material costs and synthetic complexity, limiting their application in high-value-added fields. The development of new preparation methods and the use of low-cost raw materials are necessary to simplify the manufacturing process and reduce production costs. Mixing ILs with appropriate organic solvents results in lower costs, reduced viscosity, and enhanced ionic conductivity. However, this mixture also leads to a decreased boiling point, which could impact the operational temperature range of GPEs. DESs exhibit properties similar to those of ILs, yet their preparation is less costly and less complex. Therefore, the development of new DESs as alternatives to ILs is desirable. The thermal stability of eutectogels should be further enhanced by exploring new composition schemes or synthesis methods to broaden the operating temperature of related FSCs. A fundamental understanding of eutectogels is also needed, particularly regarding issues such as their physicochemical, electrochemical, and thermal properties, as well as the effects of DES constituents and hydrogen bonding networks on these properties. On the other hand, frequently used salts in WIS-GPEs, such as LiTFSI, are expensive, exhibit low conductivity, and their large ionic size hinders the penetration of ions into electrode pores [184,185]. The discovery of new salts with high solubility, low-cost and small-sized anions for WIS-GPEs is thus necessary to reduce manufacturing costs and enhance the performance of associated FSCs. The dissolution of dual/multiple salts is worth to be tried. It also allows an increase in salt concentration, accompanied by a reduction in the amount of free water, leading to an increased boiling point, a widened potential window and an expanded operating temperature of the electrolyte. Compared to liquid electrolytes, the ionic mobility in GPEs is slower due to intermolecular interactions between ions and polymer chains. It is important to improve the ionic conductivity of GPEs to facilitate ion transfer, which could be attained through the addition of conductive particles or by increasing the proportion of plasticizer, etc. Utilizing redox-active GPEs, either by direct incorporation of redox species or through the development of polymers or ILs containing redox-active groups, represents another potential solution. In this way, extra capacitance could be generated through redox reactions of these redox mediators, leading to enhanced energy storage capacity of FSCs. The electrochemical behavior of these redox species at higher temperature, and the effect of redox species on the thermal-electrochemical properties of GPEs should be addressed. GPEs incorporate various components, including single, dual or multiple electrolytic compounds, pure or mixed solvents, polymer networks, and fillers. Some issues, such as the confinement effect of polymer host on electrolytic compounds and the interfacial properties between gels and nanofillers, have not been fully understood. The influence of individual components and the interactions between these components on the thermal, mechanical, and electrochemical properties of GPEs need to be clarified via both experimental and computational methods. This can provide guidance for the design of GPEs used in HT-FSCs. For example, a thorough understanding of the interaction of co-solvents with other electrolyte components, such as salts, water and polymers, is essential for the selection of suitable co-solvent(s) and the determination of their proportion. The flexibility of GPE films can be studied through theoretical models (e.g., elasticity theory models for the deformation and stress distribution in thin films, and molecular dynamics simulations for the mechanical behavior of thin films at the atomic level) and experimental tests (e.g., tensile tests, indentation tests, and in-situ techniques such as atomic force microscopy and SEM for real-time observation of thin film deformation during loading). The synergy between theoretical and experimental approaches provides insights for refining the mechanical properties of GPEs. (2) Electrodes. The development of advanced electrode materials for HT-FSCs is crucial for achieving high performance and longevity of these devices under high-temperature operations. They must have good chemical stability, mechanical robustness, high specific surface area, good cycling stability, good compatibility with GPEs, and ability to withstand high temperatures [186,187]. Taking conductive diamond as an example. It shows properties of chemical inertness, a wide electrochemical potential window, a low coefficient of thermal expansion, high thermal and mechanical stability. Diamond electrodes can withstand high temperatures and maintain their performance over a wide range of temperatures, making them suitable for high-temperature SC applications. The high mechanical robustness of diamond ensures high stability of flexible diamond electrodes in dynamic environments or under mechanical stresses during operations. By tailoring nanostructure and porosity of diamond electrodes, optimized performance of HT-FSCs can be achieved. Under high temperature operations, the stability of electrode materials can be affected by chemical reactions, structural changes and phase transitions, leading to reduced performance and cycle life of related FSCs. Appropriate characterization and thorough testing of electrode materials are essential to ensure their ability to withstand high temperature and their suitability for HT-FSCs. It is known that the combination of two or more materials lead to the creation of new composite materials that possess different properties over the original materials. However, the difference in thermal expansion behavior between different solid materials would result in the generation of stress at interfaces that increases with rising temperature, leading to limited operating temperature. Therefore, it is crucial to reinforce the interfacial bonding between the various components of a composite, which can be achieved through surface treatment of each component, the introduction of an interfacial layer, and the application of pressure during the synthesis process, etc. Additionally, impurities (e.g., water and functional groups) on electrodes affect the thermal and electrochemical performance of HT-FSCs. For example, the presence of a small amount of water may result in thermal and electrochemical instability of the electrode, a reduced cell voltage window, and an increase in internal resistance. Appropriate pretreatment of electrode materials should be carried out to remove or modify these impurities, aiming to eliminate their negative effects. The thermal stability of other electrode components, like binders and current collectors, also need to be considered to ensure good thermal performance of electrodes. The presence of polymer binders has been reported to have negative effects on the performance of electrodes. These include decreased surface area of active materials accessible to electrolyte ions, increased electrical resistance of electrodes, increased complexity and cost for electrode preparation, and susceptibility to decomposition and collapse at high temperatures [188]. Binder-free electrodes that eliminate the need for binders hold significant promise for overcoming these limitations. They could be produced by synthesis of free-standing films or direct growth of active materials on current collectors. Without the contribution of binders to the overall performance of electrodes, binder-free electrodes permit more efficient utilization of active materials. (3) Construction and performance of HT-FSCs. The cell voltage and the operating temperature range of an HT-FSC is determined by the electrochemical/thermal stability of its electrode/electrolyte systems. Matching GPEs with appropriate electrode materials is crucial for achieving high-performance HT-FSCs. For instance, aligning the pore size in electrode materials with the size of electrolyte ions can result in high capacitance. The compatibility and interaction between the electrode and electrolyte are of great significance to ensure efficient ion transport across the two phases. Interfacial resistances in HT-FSCs are typically higher than those in SCs using liquid electrolytes, primarily due to poor electrode-GPE contact, which may further deteriorate under elevated operating temperatures and/or during cycling processes. Incorporating interlayers and applying interface coatings are possible ways to improve interfacial kinetics. Fundamental investigations of interfacial phenomena are required for addressing interfacial issues and understanding the temperature-dependent energy storage mechanisms in HT-FSCs. The performance of HT-FSCs is highly dependent on the heat transfer and temperature distribution within the devices, which are affected by the composition of the components, the interface between different parts, operating conditions (e.g., temperature and cell voltage), and internal electrochemical charging/discharging processes, etc. Ensuring a proper temperature distribution is essential for maintaining uniform conditions throughout the cell, especially for HT-FSCs at a large scale. This prevents the formation of hot spots, which could negatively impact performance and durability and potentially trigger thermal runaway. Accurate experimental and numerical methodologies are required for a comprehensive understanding of thermal transport properties and thermal behavior in cells. A numerical simulation can be performed by developing a numerical model and subsequently solving the heat transport equations using the finite element method [189,190]. Neural networks represent another method, where substantial datasets are required. Their accuracy is directly correlated to the amount of data available and the training methodology applied. In order to evaluate the electrochemical performance of HT-FSCs at high operating temperatures, many studies tested CV, GCD, and EIS curves. However, these tests cannot fully reflect the performance of a device, nor can they evaluate its practical application. The flexibility, self-discharge behavior, and cycling stability of a device at high temperatures should also be studied. It is necessary to establish standard methods for evaluating the performance of HT-FSCs in a more reliable and comparable manner. The variations in the physical and chemical features of electrode materials and GPEs, the formation of the electrode–electrolyte interphase, and their relationship with changes in electrochemical performance, which have been rarely investigated, should be examined. Computer simulations (e.g., first-principles simulation and molecular dynamics simulation) can be used to model and predict the temperature-dependent electrochemical behaviors in HT-FSCs, such as interactions and electron transfer between the electrode and the electrolyte, the structure of the electrolyte in the vicinity of the electrolyte/electrode interface, intermolecular interactions within GPEs, and ion transfer along with adsorption and reaction processes on the electrode surface. By simulating charge accumulation and electron transfer behaviors in HT-FSCs, the impact of different electrode materials and GPEs (e.g., types, compositions, structure and functional groups) on the performance of integrated cells could be systematically investigated. Real-time monitoring of HT-FSCs during their charging/discharging operation under different temperatures via in-situ characterization techniques (e.g., in-situ Raman spectroscopy, in-situ TEM and SEM, in-situ thermal analysis, in-situ electrochemical spectroscopy, in-situ electrochemical quartz crystal microbalance, and in-situ EIS) is another favorable strategy to detect the influence of temperature on their electrochemical processes and the properties of different components involved. For instance, electrochemical quartz crystal microbalance technology allows for real-time measurement of mass changes in thin films during charging/discharging processes at different temperatures, providing valuable insight into the dynamic behaviors of these films (e.g., deposition, dissolution, or interactions occurring within these films). Experimental data can also be utilized to verify the validity of theoretical models and offer valuable insights for their refinement. By combining the results of on-site technical analysis with data derived from mathematic simulations and computer-assisted approaches, a deeper understanding of the electrochemical behaviors of HT-FSCs under high-temperature conditions could be gained. This is essential for the design of robust and efficient HT-FSCs suitable for a wide range of applications under extreme conditions. Additionally, the utilization of artificial intelligence and machine learning technologies for the design and synthesis of electrodes and GPEs with high functionality, and subsequently the construction of HT-FSCs with exceptional performance, holds promising prospects. By analyzing vast databases and predicting target data (e.g., material properties and the performance of HT-FSCs), these technologies facilitate the discovery of new materials, the optimization of their compositions and structures, the improvement of synthesis processes and conditions, and the selection of optimal materials and configurations for HT-FSCs. The construction of novel HT-FSCs, like redox-electrolyte enhanced HT-FSCs, asymmetric HT-FSCs and metal-ion HT-FSCs, is possible ways to further improve the performance of HT-FSCs [18,191–193]. The varied energy storage mechanisms in different electrode/electrolyte systems result in different energy storage capability of the negative and positive compartments in these HT-FSCs. Therefore, the matching of the electrochemical properties of positive and negative electrode/electrolyte systems is necessary. Other factors, like mechanical properties and thermal properties should also be taken into consideration. Additionally, the development of HT-FSCs with multiple functions is a rapidly growing area of interest [194]. For example, HT-FSCs with thermal resistance, self-healing ability, wearability, and biodegradability could be adaptable to different working environments, expanding the application areas of these devices. (4) Commercial cells. HT-FSCs are of great interest to some industries that involve operations in harsh and high-temperature environments, notably in applications like electronic systems onboard aircraft and satellites, power supplies for automated systems in manufacturing (e.g., metal and glass production), medical devices used in sterilization processes, downhole tools and equipment in the oil and gas industry, and equipment in military. For instance, temperatures during downhole drilling can exceed conventional limits, reaching up to 120 °C or even higher. The integration of HT-FSCs guarantees reliable and efficient energy storage and supply, enhancing the resilience and performance of these systems in demanding environments. It should be noted that the temperature distribution in FSCs is influenced not only by operating temperatures but also by the heat generated during the charging/discharging processes. The degree of heating in a cell, which is influenced by factors such as voltage, current, the duration of discharging/charging, and internal resistance, can result in a significant temperature rise. This necessitates the use of HT-FSCs in some applications in non-high-temperature environments, such as regenerative braking systems in electric vehicles and hybrid electric vehicles, portable electronics, etc. Nevertheless, research on HT-FSCs as commercial cells still lags behind. The current methods used to synthesize most thermally stable GPEs are not highly feasible for industrial processes. To address the technical challenges associated with commercialization, highly scalable synthesis techniques for GPEs need to be developed. The scalable manufacturing of electrode materials is another concern demanding attention. CRediT authorship contribution statement Chong Peng: Writing – review & editing. Chong Peng received his BS degree in 2021. Under the supervision of Assoc. Prof. Siyu Yu, he received his MS degree from Southwest University in June 2024. His research centers on developing high-temperature-tolerant flexible supercapacitors using carbon based electrodes and gel polymer electrolytes. Xinyi Huang received her BS degree in 2022. She is currently pursuing her MS degree at Southwest University. Her research focuses on the design and developing of gel polymer electrolytes for high-temperature-tolerant flexible supercapacitors. Quanhong Yang joined Tianjin University as a full professor in 2006 and was promoted to a Chair Professor in 2016. His research interests are focused on functional carbon materials and low dimensional materials for energy storage and environmental protection. Specifically, he has made significant advances in interfacial assembly of low dimensional materials, compact energy storage, catalysis in Li-S batteries, and the conversion of air pollutants into energy storage materials. Nianjun Yang has been a Professor of Electrochemistry and Catalysis at the Department of Chemistry and Institute of Materials Research (IMO-IMOEC) of Hasselt University (Belgium) since March 2023. His Habilitation in the fields of Materials Science and Surface Engineering finished in 2020 at the University of Siegen. He works on the design,synthesis, and electrochemical applications of various functional materials. Siyu Yu is currently an associated Professor at Southwest University (Chongqing, China). She received her Ph.D. degree in Engineering in June 2018 from University of Siegen (Siegen, Germany). Her current research interests are the design and synthesis of advanced energy storage nanomaterials, and the construction of high-performance supercapacitors.

coredata.dc:description: The development of flexible supercapacitors (FSCs) capable of operating at high temperatures is crucial for expanding the application areas and operating conditions of supercapacitors. Gel polymer electrolytes and electrode materials stand as two key components that significantly impact the efficacy of high-temperature-tolerant FSCs (HT-FSCs). They should not only exhibit high electrochemical performance and excellent flexibility, but also withstand intense thermal stress. Considerable efforts have been devoted to enhancing their thermal stability while maintaining high electrochemical and mechanical performance. In this review, the fundamentals of HT-FSCs are outlined. A comprehensive overview of state-of-the-art progress and achievements in HT-FSCs, with a focus on thermally stable gel polymer electrolytes and electrode materials is provided. Finally, challenges and future perspectives regarding HT-FSCs are discussed, alongside strategies for elevating operational temperatures and performance. This review offers both theoretical foundations and practical guidelines for designing and manufacturing HT-FSCs, further promoting their widespread adoption across diverse fields.
